Vanessa’s hair turned grey.”“So in other words, La Belle Dame’s victims are all male?” Holly asked.Mr Tufnell nodded. “Not one of them could resist her charms. In death as in life. Youand Mr Cubbins would need to beware, Mr Lockwood.”Lockwood chuckled. “Oh, I think George and I could handle whatever La Belle Damemight throw at us. Wouldn’t you say so, George? Very well, Mr Tufnell, we’ll look intothis for you. Give us twenty four hours to research the case. If you think that givesCharley enough time?”  ​Our visitor looked at the chained boy, motionless and blank-eyed at his side. “I wouldhope so, Mr Lockwood… But for pity’s sake, don’t delay too long.”I was glad to see our clients go: I disliked one, and pitied the other. In short, theirpresence disturbed me. I led them to the door.As I opened it and stood aside to let them pass, Mr Tufnell bowed to me. As he didso, he let the chain go loose in his hand. At once, Charley Budd pulled sharply to the side,tearing the chain free. He fell against the opposite wall, beside the big chipped plant potwith its umbrellas and rapiers. Hands still bound together, he grasped the hilt ofLockwood’s second-best sword and wrenched it up, out of the pot, so the blade shone inthe morning light. Then he thrust it down and inwards, seeking to drive the tip deep intohis stomach. His arms were too short, the blade too long. It stabbed into the leather of hisbelt and caught

short, the blade too long. It stabbed into the leather of hisbelt and caught there.While he struggled to free it, I was on him, grappling at the blade. Mr Tufnell caughthis arm, pulling at the chain. The youth fought back frenziedly, desperately, withfrightening strength. We collided with the coat-rack, then the key-table. He made nosound. For several silent seconds, we wrestled back and forth, his pale face next to mine,our eyes locked together. Then Mr Tufnell clouted him hard on the side of the head and Ipulled the rapier away.Like a switch had been flicked, Charley Budd was placid again. His face was calmand expressionless; he allowed himself to be led out of the door and into the sun.“I’m so sorry,” Mr Tufnell said, turning at the gate. “You see now how finding theghost really is his only chance? Please do everything you can to help us.”With that he raised his battered felt hat, tugged at the chain and led the boy awayalong the road.

6. If we had been largely unmoved by Mr Tufnell – his combination of sleazy theatricalbombast and slippery evasion wasn’t wildly attractive – the evident plight of CharleyBudd affected us all. According to Lockwood, who knew such things, it was a rareexample of psychic enchainment, in which the victim’s mind was snared.​“It’s like ghost-lock,” he said, “but it’s not the body that’s been trapped this time, butthe intelligence. The will to live just seeps away and the victim is pulled towards death.Tufnell’s right – destroying the ghost is probably the only way to sever the connection.”​“Poor boy.” Holly was tidying up the mess left in the hall. “How awful to want to dothat to himself.”​“His eyes were empty,” I said. “When I fought him, there was nothing there.”​“And did you see his blank, inexpressive face?” George added. “Eerie.”​“Well, it’s clearly a formidable spirit that’s snared him,” Lockwood said, “and there’sno way I’m facing it until we’re properly prepared. Can you look into the story whenyou’re at the Archives, George? I’ll order more equipment; we left half our stuff in themausoleum.”​“Lots to do,” George said. “Marissa, the Problem, and La Belle Dame Sans Merci. I’dbetter get off. Before I do, I wanted to show you the stuff I found in your parents’ crates,Lockwood. Mind if I quickly do that now?”​We followed him upstairs to the first floor. It was a place where the representatives ofDEPRAC, checking on our activities in the basement office, never thought to go. Whichwas lucky for us, because it contained a dark and terrible wonderland, filled with thingsthat threatened one’s health and sanity, and I’m not just talking about George’s bedroom.There was another room there that had once belonged to Lockwood’s sister, Jessica – theroom she’d died in. Here her death-glow hovered perpetually above the stripped-backbed, and stacks of crates lined the walls, each stamped with faded export permits fromforeign lands. And set out on the one clear area of floor, surrounded by a circle of ironchains, were selected items from those crates: items strange, dangerous and forbidden.  There were masks, fashioned in the shape of wild animals and monstrous spirits.There were cloaks, one covered in feathers, one in moulting fur. There were peculiarconstructions of bone and feather and strings of animal gut, threaded with multicolourediron beads, that Lockwood said were Javanese ghost-catchers. And there were pots,sealed with lead and wax. These in particular we treated with extreme caution. It was inthe breaking of one of these that Jessica Lockwood had lost her life eight years before.​It was quite a haul. The tweedy, placard-waving ghost-cultists, who paraded throughTrafalgar Square most days, would have fallen on their knees before the items on display.Fittes researchers would have sold their grandmothers to have seen them. Rich collectorswould have fought each other for them tooth and nail, while relic-men would have cutour throats and pinched them while we slept. Inspector Barnes of DEPRAC would simplyhave arrested us and confiscated the lot. So it was that we took care to ensure that thecollection remained secret, known by nobody except us, Kipps and Flo.​We stood at the door, looking in. George indicated a row of dusty looking green-glassbottles set out inside the chains. “These are what I found yesterday,” he said. “Spiritbottles. Places to trap annoying

he said. “Spiritbottles. Places to trap annoying or unwelcome ancestors. The old shaman would pop aSource inside – it was generally a bit of bone – and seal it up: presto, the ghost’scontained. The interior’s lined with iron, of course. Basically they do the same job as theskull’s glass jar, only they’re superior in a way, because you don’t get the horrid visuals.”​“Same sort of thing as the pots, then?” Lockwood asked. He pointed at a group ofred-clay pots, inscribed with strange characters. I’d have thought they’d have remained

indecipherable for a hundred years, but I hadn’t reckoned with George. He’d figuredthem out during a wet afternoon at the library.“Pretty much,” George said. “You know, I’m beginning to think that everything yourparents brought back has some kind of psychic significance. Even the stuff hanging updownstairs. They were very good researchers. Think I’d have liked them.”“I’m sure you would.”I was watching Lockwood’s face. His face was calm, but his eyes were curiouslyunfocused; he was staring out at nothing, or perhaps into the past.Celia and Donald Lockwood had been researchers into the folklore of ghosts, andtheir speciality had been the beliefs of far-off countries. Not only did they travel there –but they had shipped back many items of interest in giant packing crates. Some of thismaterial had ended up on the walls of 35 Portland Row, but much remained in boxes,having arrived in Britain after their unexpected deaths. We had only begun to investigatethese recently, and had at once unearthed two marvellous feathered cloaks, or spirit-capes, that had been worn by Indonesian shamans while conversing with their ancestors.Lockwood and I had discovered that the protective properties of these capes were notmere legend: they had shielded us when we walked the icy paths of the Other Side.Without them, we would certainly have died.​One of the capes was lost; the other remained with us, locked in the storeroom in ouroffice basement, next to our supplies of coke and beans and crisps. It was to find out whatelse the crates might hide that we had begun operations in Jessica’s room.​“The thing is,” George went on, “half these bottles are cracked. We need to be verycareful with them for obvious reasons.” He glanced at Lockwood. “If you want we couldtake them to the Furnaces. Might be the safest thing to do.”​“No…” Lockwood said. “They may come in useful. If they’re kept inside the chainsthey should be safe enough.”“Well, don’t sneeze near them,” George said. “That’s my advice. It’s a mini-clusterwe’ve got right there. Imagine if they all got out.”​“Yes, imagine…” Lockwood’s glance lingered on the death-glow hovering above thebed. Then he turned the light off and closed the door. We didn’t have any jobs scheduled in that evening. This was a good thing, as we neededto get ready for the Belle Dame case the next day. Through the afternoon I restocked ourbelts; Lockwood rang Mullet’s, and ordered more rapiers and chains. Then he and Hollydid paperwork for recent cases. George was off at the Archives and didn’t return. Atteatime I fixed a hurried meal, re-heating one of George’s old stews from the freezer. Weate it in the basement office. Holly went home. George was still out. It was justLockwood and me at Portland Row.​I was tidying up in the kitchen when Lockwood peered round the door.“I was just nipping out, Lucy. I wondered if you’d like to come along.”“On a case?”“Of a kind.”“You want to go now?”“If you’re not doing anything important.”I so wasn’t. In seconds I’d joined him at the door. “You want me to get my kitbag?” Isaid. “I can easily nip down.”“It’s okay. Your rapier should be fine.”So it wasn’t a tough ghost, then. We set off up Portland Row. “Are we going far?”“No. Not far.”We walked east

we going far?”“No. Not far.”We walked east a couple of blocks, then turned north towards the Euston Road. Iwondered if we were going to hail a cab at the depot there, but before we reached theintersection Lockwood halted beside the rusted girdle of iron panelling that surroundedthe Marylebone Cemetery.“Here?” I said. It was a small abandoned cemetery, heavily salted, and well-encasedin iron.“Yes.”“I hadn’t heard about trouble here.”

He smiled slightly. “If you put your boot in the ivy just beside you, you’ll find a postyou can stand on. Then you can catch hold of the top of the panels and swing yourself up.There’s a brick wall behind the iron. We can climb down it. Look, I’ll show you.”In moments he was standing, crouched and cat-like, just beyond the top of thepanelling. “Think you can do that? If you reach out, I could help pull you up.”My only reply was a snort. And I may not have been quite as nimble, and myscrambling might have been accompanied by a tad more swearing, but I was soon besidehim, ten foot above the pavement, looking down into the dark green amphitheatre of theovergrown cemetery.We were standing on the top of the original stone wall, concealed from outside by theiron panels. Away to our right burned the dull lights of the Euston Road. Below us,silence and shadow held sway. It was an old-style inner city graveyard, where space hadbeen at a premium. The headstones were set almost on top of each other, and were largelysubmerged beneath a thicket of brambles, with the tallest urns and angels cresting thefoliage like boats on a turbulent green sea. Fingers of ivy clung to the inside of theboundary wall. Here and there, old yews emerged like melting candles, joined to thethicket below by strings of ivy and trailing vines. The ground was choked. The cemeteryhad evidently been abandoned for some time.It looked a melancholy patch of ground, not particularly threatening. Equally, it wasnot an easy place to swing a sword. “What kind of Visitor is it?” I asked.A cool wind was coming along between the houses, and Lockwood’s coat fluttered athis back as we stood together on the wall. He didn’t seem to have heard me. “Gettingdown’s easy enough,” he said softly. “The wall’s crumbling here. It’s almost like astaircase, as long as you don’t skid. Shall we go?”“Lockwood,” I asked, as I eased myself after him. “How do you know about all this?”“I’ve been here before,” he said. “And now,” he added, as I landed in a clear strip ofgrass with waist-high brambles all around, “we just nip along there.” He pointed to whatlooked like an animal trail running off between the stones.I let him lead the way, keeping my head low to avoid the thorns arching above. Thetrack wound among the gravestones and soon opened into a small cleared space wherethe foliage had been crushed underfoot, and the ivy chopped back with a sword.Two headstones stood in the centre of the space. One of the last rays of sunlight wasshining on them. They were made of grey stone: modern, sharp-edged and unsullied bywind or rain. Neither was ornate, but the one on the left was larger. It was crowned by acarving of a beautiful, sad-faced woman in a hooded cape. On the plinth below, in strongclear letters, was written:Celia LockwoodDonald LockwoodKnowledge sets us free The second stone was just a simple slab, inscribed with two words only:Jessica Lockwood “Oh, Lockwood,” I said.He stood beside me in the dark, face almost lost behind the raised collar of his coat. “Isometimes wonder what it’s all about,” he said. “Why we do what we do. When we havenights like last night, for instance – why we put ourselves through all that. Or whentwerps like Tufnell come bleating and blustering in at our door, and we have to sit therehumouring him. When I get that kind of thought, I sometimes pop in here.”My heart was too full to say anything. I stood and gazed at the stones. I’d sometimeswondered where they were, his

and gazed at the stones. I’d sometimeswondered where they were, his missing family. But I’d never dared ask him. And now hewas sharing this most private of places with me.“This is what the Problem means,” he went on. “This is the effect it has. Lives lost,loved ones taken before their time. And then we hide our dead behind iron walls andleave them to the thorns and ivy. We lose them twice over, Lucy. Death’s not the worst ofit. We turn our faces away.”​On the far edge of the tiny clearing an older headstone had toppled almost to thehorizontal. Lockwood went to it; he sat cross-legged on the stone, with brambles spunclose about him. His dark clothes merged with the shadows; his smile floated palely in

the half-light. “I usually perch on this,” he said. “Belongs to a sadly deceased personcalled Derek Tompkins-Bond. I always wonder about him.”I turned slowly from the graves. “Whether his spirit will object to you sitting here?”“More what his parents were thinking. I mean, if your surname is Tompkins-Bond,it’s rather a pity to call your son ‘Derek’, don’t you think? Anyway, he doesn’t seem tomind me being here, old Derek. At least, he’s never showed up to tell me so.” He pattedthe stone beside him. “Come and join me if you want. But watch out for that rail.”I looked down. Sure enough, I’d almost tripped on a black metal rod, no higher thanankle height, that ran through the grass at my feet. I knew what it was: a boundary rail,used in cemeteries to mark the edge of a plot. I hadn’t noticed it before, but now I sawthat the Lockwood headstones were set in their own railed-off family plot. And I noticedtoo that while the parents’ stone was set in the centre of this space, and Jessica’s stonewas to the right, there was an empty area on the left-hand side.I looked at this bare patch of grass. And when I did so everything faded out – thebeating of my heart, the whisperings of the wind as it worked its way through the holesand hollows of the ivy, the sound of distant night-cabs on the Euston Road.I gazed at it. At the unobtrusive patch of ground, at the empty, waiting grave.It took me a moment to realise Lockwood was still talking. “They’d already shut thecemetery when my sister died,” he said. “There was some controversy about putting herhere. But when there are family plots, where it’s the clear intention that people should beburied together, it’s considered correct to honour the wishes of the dead.”He didn’t need to say why. Keep the dead happy. Don’t give them a reason to comeback.I stepped over the rail, crossed the grass and sat on the stone beside him.“It’s nice, don’t you think,” Lockwood said, “keeping the family together? Anyway,”he added, after a pause, “I come here sometimes.”I nodded. I was looking at the stamped, sliced foliage, chopped and broken andsavagely hacked back. “Thanks for bringing me here,” I said.“That’s all right.”We sat in silence for a time. At last I was emboldened. “You never told me how ithappened.”​“My parents?” He paused so very long that I thought he was refusing to talk of it, ashe had so often before. But a strange relaxation had laid itself upon him in that place.When he spoke, his voice was soft; it carried no barbs or warning signs. “Funnilyenough,” he said, “it wasn’t far from here.”​“What? In Marylebone?”​“On the Euston Road. You know where that underpass is, a bit further along? There.”​I stared at him. “You never told me.” The underpass was a short, ugly, concrete tunnelwhere the Euston Road ducked underground to avoid intersecting with another importantstreet. Night-cabs drove us through it all the time, Lockwood and me. He’d never givenme the slightest inkling. “So it was a car accident?” I said.​He drew one knee up, clasped it with his hands. “Quite a spectacular one. It was whenI was [four]. My mother and father were setting off to Manchester to give an importantlecture. It was meant to be a summary of all

off to Manchester to give an importantlecture. It was meant to be a summary of all their researches, all their findings. But theynever even reached the station. In the underpass their cab was struck by a lorry carrying aload of animal fertilizer, which ignited along with all the spilled fuel. It took almost anhour for the fire to be put out. It was so hot they had to re-lay a portion of the road.”​“My God, Lockwood…” I reached out in the dark and touched his arm.​“It’s all right. It was a long time ago. I barely remember them.” He smiled at mesidelong. “It’s odd, but what saddens me most sometimes is that their lecture was lost too.I’d have liked to have read that, somehow… Anyway, what with the fire, it took ages foridentifications to be made. So it wasn’t until late that police officers came to our door. Iremember looking down from the attic window, seeing their armoured vehicle blockingPortland Row, with all the lights flashing and the agents who protected them standing onthe pavement while they spoke with Jessica and our nanny. They were Fittes agents,incidentally. I remember being fascinated with the colour of their silver-grey jackets.”

​A long pause. Dusk deepened about us; leaves merged. I didn’t say anything.  ​“So they told Jessica then,” Lockwood went on. “But no one told me till the followingmorning – which was completely pointless, as I’d listened to it all from the top of thestairs. Pointless twice over, because I’d known about it hours before anyone, when I sawmy parents’ Shades watching me in the garden.”​I wasn’t surprised. He’d told me that once before. They were his first ghosts. Isqueezed his arm. “You knew they were dead?”“Not exactly. Maybe deep down. Turns out I saw them at the exact time of theaccident… Anyway, that was how that happened. My sister’s story, you already know.And now there’s just me.” A sudden burst of energy seemed to pass through him, like anelectric charge. He sprang up from the stone. “Well, there’s no good talking about it. Weshould be getting back.”I drew in a long breath. In the same way that the graveyard was choked with thewinding weeds and brambles, my head felt full now, choked with Lockwood’s memories.It was no different from the sensations I got when I picked up psychic feedback throughthe power of Touch. They didn’t feel like second-hand emotions. It was like I’d beenthere, like I’d lived them myself. I got up slowly. “I’m so sorry, Lockwood,” I said.“What an awful thing.”“Like I say, coming here helps remind me what it’s all about.” He frowned into thedark. His mood had altered, become suddenly brittle. “Everything comes back to theProblem, doesn’t it? My parents die while out searching for a solution to it. A ghost killsmy sister. While we’re still here, we have to fight against it too. There’s nothing else wecan do.”“‘While we’re still here?’” I said softly. He was looking towards the family plotagain, and at that little patch of empty ground.​Lockwood shrugged. “Well, it’s all so random, isn’t it? Everything about the Problemis so stupid and arbitrary. That Charley Budd we saw today. Why was he snared, and notsomeone else? Why wasn’t Tufnell taken? Why did my sister die and not me? There’s nomeaning to any of it. We can’t choose the manner of our passing, can we? All we can dois try to make it count. Come on. If you’re ready, we should go.”​He took a few paces across the clearing. I didn’t follow him. I stood between him andthe headstones, arms on hips, seeking to block them out.“But there is meaning, Lockwood,” I said, raising my voice. “We just have to find it.If Marissa’s at the heart of all this, we need to expose her – make her pay. There areanswers, Lockwood. We know there are. We just need to keep on searching.”He turned back to me. His sword glimmered in the half light, but his form was almostlost in the surrounding press of thick, dark green. When he spoke, his voice carried itsold, easy ring. “You’re quite right, Luce,” he said, “and I think we’re almost there. Let’shope George has something good for us tomorrow. But now we should get some rest forwhatever awaits us at that haunted theatre. I’ve kept you out too late. Are you coming?”“Yes, of course I am.” But I was looking back at the waiting grave. ​7. “So, how’ s it going with Lockwood? Pretty well?”I was first down

how’ s it going with Lockwood? Pretty well?”I was first down to the kitchen next morning. The ghost-jar had been on the table allthe previous day, its lever shut, its plaintive pulsations ignored. We’d been too busy tohumour it; even so, I did feel slightly bad that I’d neglected it all that time. I flicked thelever in the top of the jar, took a mug from the cupboard, and put the kettle on. Slice ithow you like, if you’re going to have a haunted skull talking to you before breakfast, youneed a cup of tea.“Yeah,” I said. “No different from normal.”“It’ s just I sense developments. I saw the pair of you slinking off alone last night.”“Spying on us again? You should get a different hobby.” I tried to look stern,disinterested and scathing all at once. “Anyway, what do I care? We were on a case.”The face nodded. “Oh, you were on a case?”

“That’s right.”“Okay. I buy that.” The ghost looked placidly at me. “Let’ s talk about somethingelse.”I hesitated, then cleared my throat. “Um, okay… Well—”“If you’re looking for a clean teaspoon, there’ s one by the sink.”“Thanks.”I opened the fridge to get some milk. As I closed the door the face in the jar gave asudden theatrical start that almost made me drop the bottle. The rubbery eyes lookedwildly in all directions; the nostrils flared, the mouth contorted in alarm. “Ooh, I smellsomething burning... Wait, wait, it’ s your pants! Your pants are on fire, you massive liar!You so weren’t on a case!”“We were too! We went to a graveyard, and—”“A graveyard?” The ghost chuckled low and long. “Say no more! In my experiencegraveyards can be used for lots of activities, not just ghost-hunting.” It gave me a slow,atrocious wink.  “I don’t know what you’re talking about.” But I could feel my cheeks flushing.The evil face grinned knowingly. “There, I knew I was right. And don’t try to tell meyou were scrapping with lots of different ghosts. I counted all your equipment out, and Icounted it all back again: you didn’t use flares or anything.”“We had our rapiers!”“I can tell when there’ s ectoplasm on a blade and when there isn’t. No, you andLockwood went for a cosy chat, didn’t you? And came back with brambles in your hair.”I spoke as lightly as I could. “Well, it was very overgrown.”“I bet it was.”My snort of disdain was fierce enough to keep the ghost quiet while I finished makingmy mug of tea. I threw the spoon in the sink and sat in the half-dark at the far side of thetable, keeping clear of the jar’s halo of green other-light. I glared intently at it, ponderingmy next move. How much to give, how much to seek. It was always a subtle andinfuriating business, bargaining with a skull.This main Talent of mine – psychic Listening – had long been considered the rarestand most imperfect of an agent’s arts. Mostly it was just about ominous sound effects:picking up the thud and drag of a body being hauled along a landing, for example, orhearing the scratches of broken fingernails along a cellar wall. Informative as these mightbe they weren’t revealing in the same way as actual words spoken by a spirit. Buttraditionally such words were often impossible to fathom. The famous refrain of the DireMaid, a spectral waif carrying a butcher’s knife that had haunted Covent Garden marketin the early years of the Fittes agency, was fairly typical. As Marissa Fittes had written inher Memoirs, there wasn’t that much you could take from ‘I skinned him and diced him’,repeated over and over. Sure, you got the basic message, but that was about it.​With most ghosts, snippets of sound like this were all you could hope for. They wereechoes of memory, rather than evidence of active intelligence. But Marissa, the mostfamous Listener of all, had also encountered certain Visitors that truly communicatedwith her, by which she meant full conversations. She classed these entities as ‘TypeThree’ spirits, and since her death (real or faked), no one else had come across them.​No one except for me.In recent months I’d experienced a gradual unfurling of my Talent, a slow, sureflowering in dark places. It had made me realise that many spirits had the ability

sureflowering in dark places. It had made me realise that many spirits had the ability tocommunicate, even if they couldn’t chat. That Revenant in the crypt, for instance: it hadgot its point across. It could still express the desire that drove it. The secret was Listeningwithout fear. Of the barriers separating the living and the dead, natural terror was thehardest to shake. But if you managed it, connection could come.Still, it had to be said I’d met nothing quite like the skull in the jar. He definitely wasa Type Three, and in many ways, most of them dubious, remained unique. Marissa hadnever mentioned how annoying wicked spirits could be.Though his mortal career was steeped in mystery, one or two facts were known aboutthe skull. As a nameless youth, he’d lived in the late Nineteenth Century, when he’dhelped the occult doctor Edmund Bickerstaff create the first recorded window onto theOther Side. This object, a so-called bone-glass, had been dug up in Kensal Greencemetery a year or two ago, and had since been destroyed. Bickerstaff himself had been

killed soon after the creation of the bone-glass, but the youth had escaped. His lateractivities were unknown. At some point, however, he had clearly come to a bad end,since his next recorded appearance, half a century later, was as a skull dredged up inLambeth sewers. The Fittes Agency, recognising his potency as a Source, had trappedhim in the jar, and the ghost had languished there ever since. Marissa Fittes had spokenwith him, albeit briefly. After that no one had done so – until me.  That counted for something. The ghost needed me just as much as I needed it, loudlythough it might deny it. I stared at the jar through the blue-grey half-light. The spectralface stared back at me.“We were going to talk about Marissa,” I began.“We were going to talk about my freedom.”I watched the steam rise from my mug, twisting, coiling like liberated ectoplasm.“Oh, you don’t want that,” I said. “What does freedom even mean? Even if I could trust you, which I clearly can’t, you wouldn’t want it anyway.Who would you talk to if you hadn’t got me?”“I’d talk to you. I’d stick around, help you out from time to time.”“Oh, sure you would. While strangling my friends.”“I’d strangle your enemies too. I’m not fussy. How’ s that for a tip-top deal?”“Absolute rubbish,” I said. “Tell you what: you want a deal? I’ll make you a properone. You give me more information on Marissa Fittes, information that helps us get to thebottom of this whole mystery – and perhaps sheds light on the causes of the Problem –and I’ll figure out some way to set you free. It’ll be a way that doesn’t involve George’suntimely death, or anyone else’s, but I’ll see what I can do.” I took a sip of tea.The face looked unconvinced. “No deaths? Doesn’t sound much fun. Anyway, we’vegone over this ground before. What more can I possibly tell you?”“Ah!” Frustration bubbled up within me. I banged the mug down on the table,sloshing brown splashes onto the Thinking Cloth. “That’s the whole point! You never tellme anything! Not really! About Marissa, about you and who you really are, about thenature of the Other Side! All insults, no facts – that’s the way it is with you!”“When you’re a ghost,” the skull said blandly, “you find facts are over-rated. You sortof leave them behind with your mortal body. It’ s all emotions and desires with spirits, asI’m sure you’ve seen. ‘I’ve lost my gold!’ ‘I want revenge!’ All that old hokum. Knowwhat my desire is?” It flashed a sudden grin at me.“Something foul, no doubt.”“To live. To live, Lucy. That’ s why I talk with you. That’ s why I turned my back onwhat waits for us on the Other Side.”“So what does wait

back onwhat waits for us on the Other Side.”“So what does wait for us there?” I spoke lightly, but my hand gripped harder on mymug. This was more like it; this was the kind of detail I was after.As ever, I was disappointed. “How should I know?”“Well, you’re dead. I should think that helps.”“Ooh, we are snarky today. paperwork to get through. A delivery of fresh iron was expected, too, andHolly and I were keen to try some new techniques in the rapier practise room. Holly and I practised with our rapiers until we were hot and thirsty and thestraw dummies hanging in the practise room were full of holes. Motes of straw floated inthe air. Outside Portland Row the afternoon drew on. The first stars showed in the sky.  ​  ​8. To get to the Palace Theatre, Stratford, in the east end of London, required taking theunderground trains, which ran until almost nightfall. Shortly before four, George, Hollyand I put on our work-belts and snapped our rapiers into position. We locked up PortlandRow and walked to Baker Street station, carrying our bags of iron. The ghost-jar, sealedand silent, was in my backpack. Lockwood was still at Mullet’s, and would travelseparately. We would meet him at the theatre door.It had been a pleasant early autumn day, heavy with warmth that piggybacked on sixweeks of hard, hot weather. The streets were still busy, but with that faint electric chargethat always builds up as dusk approaches. The people moved ever more quickly, theirfaces set, intent on getting their jobs done. The sun was low now. Slanting rays sliced thehouses into triangular slabs of light and shadow.As we neared the Euston Road, we passed an alley long abandoned by the sun. alley long abandoned by the sun. Fromamong the bin bags piled in its mouth a misshapen figure rose; it lurched towards us,arms out, rags fluttering, carrying with it the smell of waste pipes and carrion.Holly jumped; I reached automatically for my rapier.“Hullo, Flo,” said George.Although it wasn’t instantly apparent to the casual observer, the apparition wasfemale and possibly not much older than me. She had a roundish, mud-flecked face from

which piercing blue eyes blinked shrewdly. Her hair, lank, dirty and yellow, was scarcelydistinguishable from the ragged margins of her wide straw hat. She wore rubber bootsand a long blue puffer jacket that never came off, whatever the weather. What might liebeneath it was the stuff of whispered legend.This was Ms Florence Bonnard, aka the notorious relic-woman, Flo Bones. Relic-menand women were professional scavengers, many armed with decent psychic abilities, wholoitered around cemeteries, refuse tips and other places on the margins of society, lookingfor Sources that had been overlooked by normal agents. They then sold these on, to ghostcults, to black market collectors, even to DEPRAC itself; basically to whoever offered thebest deal. Flo’s patch consisted of the murky, mud-flecked banks of the Thames, and thisshe roamed with a sinister hessian bag that contained God-knew-what damp horrors. Sheliked liquorice, George and Lockwood, in a somewhat unclear order, and just abouttolerated me. Along with Kipps, she was an important, if unofficial, associate ofLockwood & Co.“All right, Cubbins,” Flo said. She grinned briefly at George, showing exceptionallybright white teeth, and – as a reluctant afterthought – nodded curtly at Holly and me.“Haven’t seen you at ours for a bit,” George said. “Been busy?”Flo’s shrug cracked the dried mud on the shoulders of her coat. “Nah. Not really.”​Though Flo did sometimes appear at 35 Portland Row, it was an uncomfortableexperience for her, venturing into a dry, roofed world. She preferred living under starsand bridges, with water lapping at her wellingtons, in an isolated and amphibiouslife.​There was a moment of silence, in which it became clear that Flo was focused onGeorge, and that George was watching her expectantly. Holly and I looked from one tothe other and back again.​“Well, so I got it, then,” Flo said. agency. They were big,muscled and impassive. At some point they had traded in their personalities for a simpleair of threat.As always, Sir Rupert was smiling. the more the merrier on thisone.” He grinned round at us, radiating energy and anticipation. As so often at the start ofa night, he was in excellent spirits. open the doors, and we walked through into the auditorium.​As a general rule, Lockwood & Co. didn’t hang out in theatres much. True, back inthe summer we’d once chased a Spectre up an alley next to the London Palladium andblasted it to atoms with a flare. As far as I knew, the theatre wall still had the outline of astartled gentleman in a top hat smudged across it in soot. Then we’d gone for a kebab.This was as close to high culture as we typically got, so I wasn’t prepared for what wesaw inside.The auditorium of the Palace Theatre was a world away from its dismal exterior. Itwas a vast dark space, twinkling with points of light; a cavern of gold. We stood in thedeepest velvet black, down amongst the stalls. Above and behind us, electric candlesshone along curved balconies, ranged with incredible steepness to impossible heights. Tothe sides, golden candelabras picked out the ranks of individual boxes, rising threestoreys high. Ahead of us, rising above the central aisle, the stage was white and spot-lit,

flanked by blood-red curtains. A number of youths were moving here, sweeping theboards, shifting brightly coloured cubes and baskets around. They worked in silence, butI could hear their hurried breathing. The acoustics were excellent – even whisperednoises carried to the far end of the auditorium.Tufnell led us up the aisle, our boots pattering on the wooden floor. High above,several long ropes hung down from the dark, some ending in trapeze bars, others tied torings fixed into the balconies. I imagined them in motion, with hurtling bodies intemporary flight. The idea made my palms sweat. It was hard to get over the scale of theplace. Far from giving clarity, the dozens of little lights merged together, flummoxing theeyes. You couldn’t pick out the details of the balconies without squinting. The ceiling waslost in the warm gold haze.We climbed steep steps at the side of the stage, and walked out into the light.“This is it, Mr Lockwood,” Tufnell said. “This is where La Belle Dame met her end.”He waved his arm at the youths, who had stopped work and were watching him. “Allright, you lot can go. Straight outside, no dallying. You know the reason why.”The stagehands trooped away. We dumped our bags and rucksacks in the centre of thestage. Ranged at the edges were wooden cubes of varying sizes, brightly coloured, withhinged lids and little doors. At the back sat an enormous blue crash-mat, knee-high andvery broad. Otherwise the surface of the stage was bare, marked by tape and scuffs ofdecades.Lockwood was gazing about him, eyes narrowed, face calm. Once,long ago, the sultan’s casket had sat here, pierced by swords, blood pouring out onto theboards. I looked at my feet, at the bland, smooth wood. I closed my eyesand Listened…As if I’d opened a sealed door, I was at once surrounded by a strange and paperyrustling, an expectant murmur. The noise was still there. the stage lights, and the auditorium’s soft haze, it was difficult to make outanything clearly. I pulled my rapier clear of its Velcro clasp. I stepped to the edge of the stage.The murmur in my head grew loud, turned to sudden wild applause. It came from allaround me, starting in the stalls, then rippling in a wave across the balconies and boxes. Ilooked up, scanning the hazy reaches.At once the sound cut out.And now: nothing. They slowly unspooled out into the light,trickling down the gentle slope towards the stage.I gripped my sword. I found myself frozen on the lip of the stage.I couldn’t take my eyes off the rivulets of blood that ran towards me between the stalls.      ​9. “She’s here!” My shout echoed out across the hall. “Lockwood! She’s here!”With that, I leaped from the stage, out over the pooling blood, my sword flashingunder the lights.
