It was a pity too that intheir shock and rage they forgot their sensible intention of safeguarding their researchlibrary, and began to fire their weapons. It had bad consequences for them.But not immediately. At first, the violence of it caught us by surprise.The grey haired woman with the tweed jacket raised her gun, and a jag of bright blueelectricity suddenly connected its nozzle with the wall beside my head. One moment itwasn’t there, the next it was. It cut across the room like a scribble drawn by a giant child.I felt its force, smelt the burning wallpaper. Sparks fizzed on my jacket and stung mycheeks. She turned the gun, scything the light towards me. I threw myself over the tablebeside the plaster bust and rolled away behind a chair. Behind me something exploded;fragments of the bust cascaded on the floor.  I peered round the chair: both women now were firing their guns; the blue flashes casteverything else into semi-darkness. There was movement everywhere, the flash ofrapiers, the rush of forms. Another flare burst; in its light, I saw the secretary getting tohis feet. His face was a Venn diagram of black and silver scorch marks. His hairsmouldered; one strand of it was on fire.At my shoulder, the skull gave a long, low chuckle. “These old geezers are completelymad! I’ve got to say I like them.”A masked figure – Kipps, I guessed – moved past, sword drawn, to be at onceconfronted by the burly, bearded man. His funnelled apparatus was connected to aconcertinaed bladder, like a bellows or squeezebox, strapped under one arm. He jabbedthis with his elbow: with a pop, a glass vial shot from the end of the funnel, missed Kippsby inches and shattered on the wall behind. Colourless liquid dripped down; a familiarfragrance filled the air.​“Is that the best you can do?” Kipps called. “Lavender water? Pathetic!”“I’ve have to agree,” the skull said. “That’ s the most wussy weapon I’ve ever seen.”​I grasped the neck of Kipps’s jersey, pulled him sharply down behind the chair. Thewatery substance was eating into the wallpaper, making it bubble and foam; small bits ofplaster dropped in wet gobbets to the floor.​“Possibly a bit of acid in there too,” I said.“Nice!” the skull said. “They’re totally insane!”Kipps and I took hold of the armchair, driving it forwards, colliding forcefully withthe bearded man. He gasped in pain. The funnel popped; a vial of acid ricocheted off theceiling and burst nearby. Elsewhere in the room, someone screamed. I had time to hopethis wasn’t Holly. And now here came the tiny wrinkled woman, firing her gunindiscriminately; a bolt of blue stabbed straight through the chair and out the

her gunindiscriminately; a bolt of blue stabbed straight through the chair and out the other side.My hands tingled with electrical charge. I dropped the chair. Running low, I rushed thewoman, striking her around the waist, bringing us both to the floor. Her grip wasloosened on the gun; I sent it flying from her hand.  Shadows moved nearby. I looked up; there was Harpoon Man, struggling to fixanother dart into his gun. There too the secretary, vertical at last and bearing down on me.And there was Lockwood, who stood directly in his path, in the centre of the smokingfloor. He had his rapier in his hand. The secretary gave a cry; he slashed downwards withhis mailed hands, finger-knives raking at Lockwood’s head. Lockwood movedballetically aside; his rapier struck them away. He kicked out at the nearest stilt-leg,sending the Secretary skittering away to collide into the other man.Beneath me, the tiny woman was wriggling frantically, snarling and spitting.“Criminals!” she shrieked.“Maybe,” I said, punching her in the jaw, “but we’re not weird, like you.”

And so it was that the members of the Orpheus Society discovered a curious thing. Itwas understandable they were a little tetchy; what with that, and their superior firepower,they’d probably assumed they’d win the day. But crazed as they were, roused to fury bythe damage to their property, they couldn’t match the ferocity that now erupted in all fourof us. I’d never punched an old lady before; I didn’t have any problem doing so now.In a way, they were unlucky, for it wasn’t really to do with them. It was a reaction thathad been building in us for days, since George. Our anger needed an outlet, and here weresome senior citizens in armour trying to kill us. That pretty much fitted the bill.During the next few minutes, we notched up many firsts. There was Lockwood,slicing off the secretary’s metal fingers, first from one gauntlet, then the other. There wasKipps, grappling with the bearded man, pulling at his whiskers and upending him; as hesought to rise, sticking his rapier straight into the motor of his bulb-gun, so that itexploded in a ball of pulsing light. And there was Holly, dodging the savage blows of thelong-haired woman; leaping to the giant wooden globe and shoving it over, so that itpinned her against the floor.Me, I’d got up, retrieved the discarded electrical gun and switched on the dial. Thetiny woman in silver armour had likewise struggled up. She rushed at me, shrieking: Iflicked the trigger, sending out a jolt of electric current that blew her straight through thenearest wall in a shower of bricks and plaster.The bearded man lay insensible beneath the smoking, twisted coils of his brassfunnel. Harpoon Man, however, had readied his gun. He levelled it at Kipps. Hollyscreamed a warning. Kipps ducked; the bolt shot over his head. I hit the man with anotherblast from the gun that sent him back into a chair and the chair back into a bookcase. Ittoppled over, burying him.The skull uttered whoops of glee. “This is great. You’re just as bad as them! Worse, infact. They don’t know what’ s hit them!”And the tide of the battle was turning. The grey haired woman had wriggled out fromunder the globe. She fled for the door. So too the secretary; hissing and clanking on hisstilt-legs, swinging his clawless metal hands. They arrived at the door at the same time,fighting with each other to be first to pass through. Lockwood and I walked after them, hewith his rapier, me holding the gun. Out into the corridor we went, towards the landing,stepping over the dust and debris and scattered bricks; also the unconscious body of thetiny woman, which lodged half in and half out of the wall.The fugitives reached the landing, at the head of the stairs. As the woman turned to godown, I caught her with a bolt of electricity that sent her through the banisters and outover the stairwell to land in a chandelier. There she swung, senseless and dangling, in asorry mess of crystal shards and smoking tweed.Here too the secretary had his final stand. Perhaps with his stilt legs, he couldn’teasily descend the stairs; perhaps his desperation had turned to defiance at the last. Eitherway, he turned and held his ground, as Lockwood approached, calm and remorseless,rapier at the ready.“You’ll die for this!” he cried. “She’ll make you pay!”He swung out blindly with an arm. Lockwood moved his body to the side, sliced withhis sword. He chopped neatly through the right stilt-leg. The secretary toppled against theruined banisters and carried straight on, out into

The secretary toppled against theruined banisters and carried straight on, out into space. He missed the chandelier;anyway, it was already taken. A moment later there was a heavy impact on the stairsbelow.  Silence in the house of the Orpheus Society. The gun in my hand was humminggently. I switched it off, let it fall to the floor. The body in the chandelier swung gentlyround and round.“Oh, is that it?” the skull said. “I was enjoying that. Bit of senseless violence doeswonders for morale. You should break in somewhere every night. There are heaps of oldpeople’ s homes in London. Let’ s choose another one tomorrow.”​Kipps and Holly picked their way among the debris of the corridor to join me on thelanding. Kipps eyed the plaster bust of the bulgy-eyed woman, still sitting on its plinth.“Funny,” he said, “that bit of missing nose doesn’t seem quite so bad now.”​Lockwood had gone downstairs to check the crumpled body of the secretary. A power-pack on the man’s back was spurting out intermittent bright blue sparks.​I looked down through the shattered banisters. “Is he dead?”

​“No.”​“Don’t think any of them are,” Kipps said.Below me, Lockwood stood up slowly. He nudged a limp hand aside with his bootand stepped past the secretary without another glance. He ascended the stairs, pale-faced,dusty, torn of coat, rapier in hand. Only on reaching the landing did he fix it to his belt.​“Can we go now, please?” Holly asked in a small voice.​Lockwood nodded. “First we need to stop off at that storeroom upstairs.” It was shortly after two a.m when we arrived back at Portland Row. It was silent in thehouse; nothing could be heard from George or Flo.Lockwood held a heavy bag, containing items from the storeroom. He lowered it ontothe table, then pulled his balaclava off. There was blood on his face. He scratched at hisflop of hair. “Check the front, Hol,” he said. “See if anyone’s watching the house. Masksoff, everyone. Gloves, too. We’ll need to get rid of these.”We threw the balaclavas and gloves by the door. Kipps took off his ruined jacket andchucked it on the pile. Holly came back from the living room.​“Can’t see anyone out there,” she said.Lockwood nodded. “Good enough.”We stood in the semi-darkness of the kitchen. The smell of smoke rose from ourtattered clothes. Our faces and hands were bruised and bloodied, our expressions blank.The same thought was going through all our minds.“So… think they recognised us?” Kipps said at last.We all looked at Lockwood. He was very pale and there was a cut on one of hischeeks. He reminded me of a certain apparition I’d seen almost a year before.“Probably not,” he said. “But I’m afraid that they, or Fittes, or Sir Rupert Gale willput two and two together very quickly indeed. They’ll know it’s us for sure. They’ll haveto act on it. Which makes it only a matter of time before—”“Before what?” I asked.Lockwood smiled at me. “Before the end. But it’s not going to happen tonight. I thinkwe’ll have a couple of days while they get their act together. Which means we should getsome sleep. First rule of any agency – rest when you can.” All very true, but I didn’t sleep well or long. I was awake before dawn and walking in thequiet house. I thought Lockwood would be sleeping on the couch in the living room, butthe door was open, the room empty.I looked into the library. The curtains were open and light was coming in, pale whiteand cold. There was a smell of wood-smoke, but the fire had burned out and the air waschilly. Lockwood sat in his favourite chair, a blanket over his knees. His reading lightshone over his shoulder, making a small, harsh circle of redundant brightness in his lap. Itilluminated the pamphlet we’d stolen from the Orpheus Society, lying open, face downbetween his hands. He had his eyes half open, and was staring towards the window.​I sat beside him on the arm of the chair, and switched off the light. “Not been to bed?”I asked.​He shook his head. “I’ve been reading my parents’ last lecture.”I waited. If he wanted to tell me, he would. I didn’t ask him.“Ghost Lore among the Tribes of New Guinea and West Sumatra,” he said, “‘apresentation given to the members of the Orpheus Society by Celia and DonaldLockwood on May 31st [2004].’ That’s what it says on the frontispiece, Lucy. Word forword. Spells it out nice

says on the frontispiece, Lucy. Word forword. Spells it out nice and clear. It was their calling card, if you like. They wanted tojoin the society. That nice man, the secretary of the society, even complimented me on itwhen we went there last year.”I had a vision of that white-haired thing on stilts, the screaming face, the slashingclaws. “You know, maybe it’s best they never joined,” I said. “Not sure they’d have fittedin.”Lockwood moved; he picked the book up gently. “I should apologise to you,” he said.“To you, Hol and Quill, for what happened back there, just before those idiots attacked

us. I’m sorry: I let you all down.”“Not at all,” I said. “You were—”“I was frozen,” Lockwood said. “I went into shut-down. I’m your leader and that’snot on. But I had an excuse,” he added, “because I was very surprised by something. No,surprised isn’t quite the right word. I suddenly understood a whole lot of things. Theycame in a rush, and rather overwhelmed me. And— well, I can show you what it was.”He opened the little book, turned the yellowed pages. “It’s two things together, really,” hesaid. “Most of this lecture is exactly what its title suggests. It gives an account of how thepeople of those countries deal with ancestral spirits. There’s lots about how the bones ofthe dead are stored in special spirit-houses set away from the village, so they’re kept outof trouble. And how the shamans or witchdoctors dress up in spirit-capes, like the oneswe’ve got upstairs, and go to the houses to consult the ancestors. That’s not so new. Theytalked about that in other papers, as you know. But then my mother and father home in onwhat they think is going on in those spirit houses…”He had found the extract he wanted; he knew the piece by heart. He smoothed out thepage and, holding it up to catch the frail light of morning, began to read: “So the wise men truly converse with the ancestors: that is one point onwhich they all insist. But there is another point too, even more incredibleto the modern ear. When they enter the spirit houses, so the wise menbelieve, they are no longer in the mortal world at all, but have passedthrough to another realm altogether. This is the realm of the ancestors, theland of death, where they can meet with ghosts on level terms. How canthis be, we asked them; how can your mortal bodies withstand the terribleconditions there (for it is not a pleasant place), and would not theproximity of the dead be fatal to you? ‘All this would indeed be true,’came the reply, ‘were it not for the stout protection afforded by our cloaksand masks. The precious materials of the cloaks shield our bodies andkeep the ancestors from touching us. The bone masks (formed from theremains of shamans of the past) allow us to see the spirits with clear eyes.’To our mind, these fragile items look scarcely capable of any of this,but the wise men are confident in their power. Yet even so, speaking withthe ancestors is not to be taken lightly. The elders regard it as a mostdangerous venture to be undertaken only in times of crisis, for the dead areroused to great excitement by their arrival, often following them back intothe living world. This is why the spirit houses are built away from thevillages, usually across streams. “You see what they’re stumbling towards, Lucy?” Lockwood said. “They’rerecording the exact same thing that’s going on here – the living travelling to the land ofthe dead. They’ve spotted everything: the way the dead get stirred up, the importance ofhaving lots of Sources piled together to create a door through, the need for bodilyprotection on the Other Side. It’s all there.”I nodded slowly. “The bit about the bone masks is interesting,” I said. “You think theyoperate a bit like the goggles Kipps got?”“I hadn’t thought of that. Yes, maybe. Though I bet the goggles are copying themasks, in just the same way that those silver capes we nicked are close copies of theoriginal spirit-capes. My poor parents go on to describe them in great detail, the waythey’re made, the types of silver

to describe them in great detail, the waythey’re made, the types of silver mesh holding them together… This was a gift for theOrpheus gang, Luce. Whatever techniques they were using beforehand won’t have been apatch on this. They’ve been taking a leaf out of my parents’ book ever since.”“They’ve been using their findings?”“I’m sure of it. And I’m sure of something else too. They may have been delighted tohear all about the clever techniques used by the shamans, but they wouldn’t have been atall chuffed about another remark in the lecture.” Lockwood flipped forward a couple ofpages, to near the end of the little book. “Listen to this,” he said. His voice sounded odd. “From what we have seen and heard at first hand, both in the NewGuinean hill country and the forests of East Sumatra, we are convinced of

the truth of the wise men’s accounts in the matter of their ancestors. Morethan that, we feel that they have much to teach us about our own problemwith our ancestors, much closer to home. We all know that the epidemic ofVisitors that Britain endures is mysterious and worsening, withoutapparent solution. Yet could it be that the prime cause of this crisis issomewhere near us, right under our noses? Are we, somehow, disturbingthese spirits? Could there be a gate, such as we have described, withmortal traffic going through it? The idea seems absurd, and yet surely itsatisfies the evidence. We feel this theory must be explored. Indeed, wedevoutly believe that our researches, made at the other ends of the earth,have the potential to unlock great mysteries near at hand. “Of course, we know there were spirit gates near at hand,” Lockwood said. “And weknow precisely who’s been going through them. My poor mother and father hadn’t got aclue. Can you imagine them in that cursed building, giving this talk, with the clocksticking and those horrible Orpheus people quietly watching them?” He shuddered. “Itwas the wider picture, the stuff about the Other Side, that interested my mum and dad.The parallels between cultures. They thought, quite reasonably, these ideas might inspirea bit of public interest at home in England. In fact they planned to give that same lectureto a public audience in Manchester a few days later. The thing they didn’t know, being allexcited and eager, and wanting to give their special friends at the society a little previewof their theories, was that it was signing their own death warrant.”His tired eyes looked up at me; our gazes locked.“The accident,” I said.“Given what they were up to, the Orpheus Society would have been very disinclinedto have my parents’ lecture heard before the world,” he said. “Which brings me to thesecond thing I realised. The date of this lecture is 31st May [2004]. That’s just two daysbefore my mother and father were due to travel up to Manchester. In other words,”Lockwood went on, “it’s two days before their car was hit in a freak accident and theywere killed in a ball of flame. Two days before they, this lecture, and their inconvenienttheories were lost to the world forever.” He tossed the pamphlet on the floor.“It wasn’t an accident,” I said.“They were murdered, Lucy. Yes.”“And you think that Marissa and the Orpheus Society—”He held my gaze. “I don’t think that, Lucy. I know.”      IV . The Siege at Portland Row​17. Whatever the drawbacks of Flo Bones’s nursing techniques – and judging by the state ofLockwood’s bedroom when we next looked in, these included a total lack of interest incleanliness, air quality and the orderly disposal of bloodied bandages – it could not bedenied that they produced results. George was sitting up in bed that morning, wedgedamongst pillows and living room cushions, with Lockwood’s best dressing gown drapedover his shoulders and a tray of cakes lying at an angle on his lap. His face was horriblydiscoloured, with the bluish-purple flush of a soft plum, and there was a white compresstaped over his left eye. Somehow he had contrived to balance his broken spectacles on his

swollen nose. He looked like an elderly owl that had recently fallen out with awoodpecker. But his one good eye was open and sparkling with intelligence, and that wasenough to have me grinning like an idiot as I sat on the bed beside him.​“Look at you!” I said. “You’re alive and awake, and sitting up and everything!”​“Not so loud.” George’s voice was stronger, but as raspy as a piece of sandpaperscouring out an ashtray. “You’ll wake poor Flo. She’s done in.” He nodded over at thecorner of the room, where a still shape in a puffer jacket lay curled up in the centre of anest of tumbled clothes. Flo’s knees were drawn up, her head rested on her hands. Shehad removed her hat, and her matted straw-blonde hair radiated round her like adeformed starfish. Her eyes were closed. She was breathing long and deeply.Lockwood blinked. “Wait! Are those my jumpers? And my best shirts tucked underher muddy boots? You’ve emptied out the contents of my drawers!”​“She needed something cosy to lie down on,” George said. “You wouldn’t deny herthat, surely.”“There are two spare duvets in the airing cupboard!”“Oh yeah. Didn’t think of them. Anyway, keep it down. She’s been ministering to meall night. In all honesty, I feel quite caked out…” With painful movements, George set histray aside. With his good eye he inspected our cuts and bruises. “What’s all this, then?You trying to steal my thunder here?”​“We’ve been out,” Lockwood said, “getting something for you.” He placed the copyof Occult Theories on the bedspread. “Hope it’s worth it.”​The lower half of George’s purpled face parted in a wonky grin. “Christmas hascome! Thank you…” He patted the pamphlet weakly. “Which was it, Fittes or Orpheus?”​“Orpheus,” Lockwood said. “Speaking of which, if you’re no longer almost dying,you might want to get reading pronto. We may not have much time.” That our raid on the Orpheus Society was a turning point, all of us knew withoutdiscussing it. First the attack on George, and now our retaliatory expedition: lines hadbeen crossed by both sides now, and there was no possibility of returning to the watchfultruce of a few days previously. Consequences were inevitable; the question was in whatform they would come. Personally I expected a rapid payback. It wouldn’t have surprisedme if Marissa Fittes and a crack DEPRAC team had shown up before lunchtime to leadus away in chains.​But nothing like that happened. The day was quiet, and Lockwood took theopportunity to make preparations. Kipps, who had crashed out overnight on our libraryfloor, was sent into central London on a shopping trip, and Flo Bones, once she hadfinally awoken, was likewise prised from George’s bedside and given a job to do.​“I need your ear out there, Flo,” Lockwood said, “I need to hear what’s being talkedabout among the relic-men. Any rumours, anything strange that’s been heard or seen,particularly if it involves Sir Rupert Gale or any of the Fittes lot. News travels fast in thecriminal underworld, and you’ve got the best antennae of anyone I know.”​“What, am I some kind of beetle now?” Flo scowled at us; she was not best pleased athaving to leave the sick-room. “George isn’t eating right yet.

to leave the sick-room. “George isn’t eating right yet. Did you see those pastrieshe left? He needs someone with him.”​“This will help him more in the long run,” Lockwood said. “Honestly, Flo. We needyou out on the streets again. This is where George needs you.”​From the expression on her face, I expected a furious Flo diatribe at this point, but shejust went all quiet and nodded, which was even more disconcerting. “All right, Locky,”she said, as she made for the door. “But you’ve put your foot in it this time. Really putyour foot in it. This is not going to end well.”​Lockwood watched her stump away down the kitchen steps into the garden. “WhatFlo says may be true,” he said, “but I don’t believe in sitting around waiting for badthings to come to us. We’ve got work to do. Lucy, do you mind nipping up with me toJessica’s room? I want to ask you something.”

“Sure,” I said. “Why?”“Just an idea I’ve got. Call it a final line of defence. It’s a bit crazy, but I need to talkit through with you.” He looked out at the sunlit gardens, the blank houses, the windmoving on the un-mown grass. “If we’re going to do it, we need to start as soon aspossible, before anything bad happens.”​But nothing bad happened to us all that afternoon.​The skull in the jar, which had been remarkably quiet and self-effacing ever since theattack on George, took note of George’s partial recovery and the strange activity nowbeginning in the house, and flared into psychic life again.“Don’t tell me,” it said, “another crisis. Or is sitting knee-deep in dangerous hauntedobjects the latest craze for all idiot agents? What are you going to do, play ‘Pass theParcel’ now? ‘When the music stops, the Source explodes and a ghost eats your face.’ Ican’t really see it catching on.”Lockwood, Holly and I were indeed sitting on the landing, outside Jessica’s bedroomdoor. In sharp contrast to our normal habit, the door was wide open, and the emanationsfrom the death-glow above the bed pulsed across the landing. We had broken open thefinal tea-crate and, amid a surf of scattered wood shavings, were unwrapping the objectsit contained. There were wooden masks and carven sticks, brightly coloured pottery jarssealed with wax, opaque glass bottles, and – our prize discovery – one resplendent cloakof iridescent feathers, pink and orange and shining in the sun. Anything that had theremotest psychic potential we piled in one corner; the rest we cast aside. It was the sameprocedure we’d used before when investigating other artefacts gathered by Lockwood’sparents, only now carried out in double-quick time.The ghost was watching us sceptically from a position outside George’s door. In Flo’sabsence, we’d wedged this open so we could keep watch on the invalid. We’d taken theopportunity to fumigate the room too, opening the window and bringing in freshlavender. Even so, Flo’s presence lingered.“Try and be serious for a moment, Skull,” I said. “I was hoping you could help ushere. We’re separating out all the strongest Sources. Some we’re sure of, but others not.”I pointed to our ‘of interest’ pile. “What do you think of these?”  The ghost sniffed dubiously. “Some are psychically dangerous,” it said, “but you’vegot a lot of tat there that I wouldn’t give house-room to. Particularly that pierced gourdHolly Munro is putting her head in – but that’ s an issue of hygiene more than anything.”​“That pointy one? I thought it was a shaman’s mask.”“It’ s worn in tribal rituals, yeah. But those guys didn’t put it on their faces, I’ll tellyou that.”​“Er, Holly…”Her voice was muffled from inside the gourd. “What?”“Oh, nothing. I like the mask! You look good. Keep it on!” I turned back to the skull.“Exact function aside, you’re saying it’s useless?”“Almost certainly. There’ s no trapped spirit in there. Those sealed pots, though –they’re more interesting. They’ve got the whiff of the grave about them. And that dream-catcher with the bamboo handle? See how the end’ s been plugged with wax? That meanssomething

handle? See how the end’ s been plugged with wax? That meanssomething too.”“A ghost?”The face in the jar grinned evilly at me. “Maybe. Isn’t it exciting? You’d best breakthem all apart and see what’ s inside.”​“Not until we’re ready.” I looked into Jessica’s room, at the black plasm burn that hadeaten away the centre of the abandoned bed. That had been caused by a ghost unleashedat the wrong moment. Lockwood had his back to it; he was calmly unwrapping anotherbundle from the crate. He seemed to have his emotions regarding his sister’s death wellunder control. I glanced again at the ghost-jar. “How’s George doing?” I asked.The ghost swivelled; it scanned the bedroom. “He’ s lying very still with his mouthopen, so he’ s either asleep or dead – all right, all right!” (I’d made a frantic move to getup.) “He’ s snoring like a puppy, so we can take it he’ s asleep.” It frownedcontemplatively. “You say his face is badly swollen… In all honesty, how can you tell?”​“Just keep an eye on him.” I reported the skull’s remarks to Lockwood and Holly.

“George has dropped off again. He still hasn’t read that book.”​“Can’t be helped,” Lockwood said. “His recovery’s the most important thing.”​George, in fact, slept most of the day, while we continued our work in theneighbouring bedroom. In the late afternoon, Kipps returned, to be followed soon after bya large delivery lorry, inching its way down Portland Row. It came from a builder’ssupply yard; under Kipps’s direction, men began unloading large sections of chipboard,tools, ropes and other materials, and dumped them in the hall. Before they could depart, aMullet’s van showed up, bringing fresh quantities of iron, salt and new magnesium flares,and there was a great kerfuffle in the street as the vehicles struggled to pass each other.​We took possession of the deliveries and shut the door on the shouting men andhonking of horns. Holly and I took organised the agency supplies, Lockwood and Kippsthe wood and tools. Very soon banging noises began downstairs.​At teatime, we gathered in the kitchen for a meal. The day was almost over, and stillthere had been no sign of our enemies, no attack, no retribution.​“It’s weird,” I said. “I was sure we’d have been arrested by now.”“I’ve been thinking about that,” Lockwood said. “I don’t think they can just arrest usup front. They know, or guess, we’d kick up a fuss and raise a lot of awkward questions.”“Or kill us,” Kipps said. He had placed a hacksaw on the table before taking his plateof sandwiches, and there was sawdust in his hair.Lockwood nodded. “That’ll certainly be their preferred option. But they can’t easilybump us off, either. It’s one thing to beat up George in the street. It’s quite another todispose of all of us. That would take a concerted effort – and would be very risky forwhoever did it, because they know we’ll be expecting it. Also, the attack couldn’t be inpublic for obvious reasons. Even Fittes can’t blatantly authorise murder. That means it’llbe done quietly, when no one’s around. And that’s why I’m expecting a night attack hereat Portland Row.”“Tonight?” I said.“We can only hope not. We won’t be ready. Give us another day and I’ll be a lot moreconfident. Then we’ll have upstairs done as well. We’ll just have to keep watch and trustto luck. Maybe it’s taking a while to get anything out of the Orpheus people – we leftthem in pretty poor shape.”“Anyone have a theory about those stilts that madman was wearing?” Kipps asked.“What possible purpose did they have?”Lockwood shrugged. “It was Other Side kit of some kind. All of it was – even theelectrical guns. All designed to keep spirits at bay. Didn’t work quite so well on us, sadlyfor them. Well, if we’ve eaten, we should get on. There’s plenty still to do.” Defending 32 Portland Row wasn’t impossible, but there were definite points ofweakness to overcome. On the ground floor, the street-front side gave little cause forworry. The old front door was thick and sturdy, and fixed with so many locks and chainsit would have needed a bazooka to blow it down. The library and living room windowswere fairly safe too, as both overlooked the basement yard, and so weren’t easilyaccessible. It was the kitchen at the back, with its steps leading down to the garden, thatworried us. That evening Kipps fixed

leading down to the garden, thatworried us. That evening Kipps fixed home-made barricades to the inside of the windowsand across the glass pane of the door. Lockwood also went out and spent quite a bit oftime constructing something on the steps below the door. “I’ve been inspired by our visitto Marissa’s tomb,” he said. “Might be best to avoid using this entrance for a few days.”He didn’t explain more.The basement had long been our main point of concern. Again, the front of the housewas theoretically less vulnerable. It was true that windows in our office opened directlyonto the sunken yard below our front door. Steep steps led down here from the gate and –though lots of dead plants in big pots filled the space – intruders could easily reach thewindows. However, following a burglary years before, we had added iron bars to these,and it was hard to see how these could be bypassed. This meant we focused all ourattention on the back.At the rear of the office, past the rapier practise room, the storeroom and the scullery– where our washing machine sat, and stiff socks and other items hung on lines – youcame to the back door. It was made of glass, and opened straight onto the grass of the

garden. Of all parts of the house, this door was the weakest point. Already Kipps hadfixed a series of wooden staves across the opening, but we doubted they’d survivesustained attack. As night fell, extra defences were added by Lockwood and Kipps, whospent a lot of time messing with the floorboards just inside the door.Holly watched proceedings from the arch that led to the rapier room. WhenLockwood finally stopped, shirt rolled up and knees scuffed and dusty, she indicated thetwo straw dummies hanging on their chains. “Anything we can rig up with Joe andEsmeralda?” she asked. “They’ve got potential too, somehow.”Lockwood nodded. “Yes, it seems a pity to leave them out,” he said. “I’ll see what Ican do.”Nightfall came. Holly and I stockpiled weapons and watched the street. Neighboursmoved about inside their houses. Arif closed up his stores. Portland Row was silent. Ourenemies made no move.Towards midnight, George woke up and asked for sandwiches and a bedside light. Hebegan reading the book. The rest of us took turns on sentry duty, two hours at a time,while the others slept.​A crescent moon rose over London and migrated slowly through the sky. At aroundtwo a.m. I sat at the living room window sill with the ghost-jar by my side. Hey, it waslate. I was tired. I needed the company.​“There’s a spirit standing on the garden path opposite,” I said. “I just caught themoonbeams going through it. So very faint. Man in a bowler hat. Very still and peaceful,like he’s thinking about something.”​Tonight the face in the jar shone pale and silvery, mirroring the moon. “Oh, him,” itsaid. “Yes, he’ s thinking about something, all right. In about twenty minutes he’ll movetowards the house and disappear. At about 3.40a.m. he’ll reappear, just briefly, with adirty big bundle over his shoulder. I reckon it’ s his dead wife wrapped in a rug, but youonly get a flash of a pair of slippers as he sets off up the road, so I’ve never satisfied mymind on that.”I stared across the street. “This happens every night? I’ve never seen it before.”“Yeah, it’ s funny how often one doesn’t see things that are right under your nose,” theghost said. “So… what shall we talk about? I know! Lockwood. He’s in his element now,isn’t he? Enemies closing in. Endgame afoot. Nice for him! He’ s chirpy.”​“Nonsense. He’s worried sick, like the rest of us.”“Is he? Then he hides it well. If it was me, I’d say he’ s more than content with the wayit’ s going. Suits the trajectory he’ s been on ever since his parents croaked. Oh, you canhuff and pout all you want, but you know it’ s true. Going out in a pointless blaze of gloryis just how he’d like it: saves him the hassle of doing the boring, complex stuff – youknow, like going on living.” The face grinned at me.​“That is such a lie.”​“Isn’t.”“It so is.”“Yes, it’ s our intellectual debates I’m going to miss when you’re dead,” the skullremarked. The eyes fixed on me. “You don’t have to stick with him, you know. You couldget out, go somewhere different, try to survive. Nip out now, you’d be on a train at dawn.I

Nip out now, you’d be on a train at dawn.I can see you’re getting all furious again, but you shouldn’t. There are options – lessnoble, but somehow more sensible – that’ s all I’m saying.”“I’m staying here.”“Fair enough. At least you’ve got the choice. Some of us don’t have that luxury.” Theface gave a sigh, swept slowly round and round against the inside of the jar.“Skull, when this is all over—”​“Don’t say you’ll let me out, because we both know that’ s a lie.”​“It isn’t. I promise. I’ll break the glass and let you go.”​“Thanks for saying it, but you’ll just stuff me back in that storeroom with all thecrisps. You’ll forget me as soon as the danger’ s over, I know.”​“I won’t. What do we need to break the silver-glass?”

​If a disembodied head could have shrugged, it would have done. “A hammer ought todo it.”​​“We’ve got hammers! Kipps and Lockwood have been using some today! Noproblem, then. That’s what we’ll do.”​The skull seemed unconvinced. “Don’t suppose you could bring the programmeforward and release me before your brutal death, could you? Might be more efficient thatway. No? Well… it was a nice thought.”​“I’m not going to die.”​“Yeah. That’ s what I said once, too.”​I didn’t deign to reply to this. We fell silent and watched the road. Despite our fears and dark predictions, the night passed without incident. No one attackedus in our beds, and the only disturbance was George calling for cheese on toast at five inthe morning. Dawn came at last, and we met again for breakfast. The kettle had only justboiled when a furious knocking sounded on the kitchen door and Flo Bones appeared,looming like a haunted scarecrow at the window. She bore ominous tidings and a rathercrumpled box of chocolates for George.“Excuse the mud splats on the cardboard,” she said, brushing at a stain on the side ofthe box. “I didn’t pass an open drain, or I’d have washed them off on the way up. Well, Isee you’ve all been busy. What’s that tripwire thing halfway up the steps?”Lockwood shut the door behind her. “Sorry, Flo. It’s a deadly man-trap. I should havetold you.”Flo reached under her hat and scratched at her scalp. “Good thinking, and it seemslike you might be needing a few more of them and all.” She broke off, and regarded uslevelly.“Why?” Holly said. “What have you heard?”She shook her head. “I don’t know as I should say, seeing as how it’ll give you all thewillies. And it ain’t confirmed, neither. Just a bit o’ hearsay what’s washed along theThames, and been gathered in her sack by old Flo. But the word is—” She glanced overher shoulder, made a lucky sign, and lowered her voice. “Word is that Sir Rupert Gale’sbeen in deep discussions with the Winkmans, and your name has been mentioned.”​“Ah, that’ s it, is it?” Lockwood breathed. “I knew there’d be a reason why they’vetaken so long.”​“I don’t get it,” Kipps said. “Why would Gale talk with a known criminal to—”​“Because they’re old acquaintances. Gale used to buy black-market Sources fromJulius Winkman. Anyway, shut up a minute, Quill. Sorry, Flo – go on.”​During the interruption Flo had helped herself to Lockwood’s mug of tea. “Yeah,Julius Winkman,” she said. “Since his release, he’s been lying low. There’s been wordsent out that he don’t want to see any relics or stolen goods or any of that stuff, though‘course,” Flo said, rolling her eyes, “that don’t mean nothing, as it’s his missus Adelaideand that young smear of cow-cake, Leopold, who take possession of all the hush-hushitems these days. So officially, old Winkman is all above-board now. But they say thatGale went to see him, and since then Julius has been out recruiting some of his oldassociates, fellows who ain’t so particular about the kind of work they do. Head-crackers,bone-breakers, knifemen and garroteurs –

they do. Head-crackers,bone-breakers, knifemen and garroteurs – that sort of tidy gentleman. Rounding them up,routing them out from the inns and wharfside stews, getting them tooled and ready for adicey and unspecified job.” Her blue eyes gazed at us from the shadows of her hat.“Unspecified… but concerning you.”​“That’ s why they’ve taken so long to get going,” Lockwood said. “Fittes and Gale aregetting the Winkman family to sort us out. Marissa keeps her hands clean and shuts usup, while Julius gets the revenge he’s been after ever since we got him arrested afterKensal Green that time. Hey presto, everyone’s happy.”​“Except us,” Holly said. “We’ll be dead.”

There was a pause while we all digested Flo’s news. “Maybe it’s better this way,” Isaid at last. “Maybe it’s better that it’s not going to be other agents. They won’t betrained, like us, will they? They won’t have swords.”“No,” Kipps said, “just guns and knives. Hooray.”No one had much to say about this. We looked at one another.“Is this a private wake, or can anyone join in?”The voice came from the hallway door. Everyone turned: there stood George. He wasin his pyjamas, and very grey about the face – grey, at least, where the purple bruisesweren’t blossoming. The bandage on his head had come away, and you could see wherethe hair was still matted with congealed blood. His sleeves were too short, and there werebruises on his arms. He stood awkwardly, limbs shaking, clasping the doorframe forsupport. But he was standing, for the first time in days.“Look at me,” he said. “Upright again! Things can’t be so bad, surely.” He gave us awonky, mottled smile. “Hey, and there’s the proof of it! Are all those chocolates for me?”  ​18. Dubious as Flo’s gift undoubtedly was (my theory was that she’d found the box floatingdown the Thames and had dried the chocolates out individually on riverside stones beforerepacking them), it was good to see George take an interest in it. And his interest in otherthings had reignited too. During the night he had read and thoroughly digested OccultTheories, the little book we had brought back from the Orpheus Society. Over breakfast,sharing tea and chocolates with Flo, he filled us in on what he’d found.​“It’s by Marissa,” he said. “No question about it. Hasn’t got her name on, but Irecognise her style from the Manual and other works. But it’s a strange piece of work.She must have written it when she was very young, because there’s nothing about beingan agent, or psychic detection or anything practical. It’s all much more airy than that, fullof weird theories about life and death. The thing that really jumps out is her obsessionwith the stuff that spirits are made of. She thinks ghosts are proof that this substance isimmortal. The body falls away, and the spirit continues on.”​“She’s talking about ectoplasm, then?” Holly asked.​“The skull said she asked him about that, too,” I said.​“I guess so,” George said, “though she calls it by other names too: ‘the soul’, ‘eternalessence’, stuff like that. The thing that’s interesting is that she reckons that if you couldsomehow capture this ‘essence’ and absorb it, it would rejuvenate your body and makeyou young again. Anyone see the significance of that?”​Everyone did. “The woman we call Penelope…” Lockwood said.  “Exactly right. Do you want that last caramel choc, Flo, or shall I have it?” Georgepopped it in his mouth and looked round at us. “The thing is, if you read Marissa’s ideas,she sounds completely cracked. And as we all know, she never went public with anythinglike that again. Soon after she wrote this, the Problem began, and it was ghost-hunting forMarissa all the way. But it seems to me,” George finished, “that she’s been quietlyworking on this pet theory of hers ever since.”​Lockwood nodded slowly. “You’ve hit it, George. That’s the answer. And if we couldget into her rooms in Fittes House, we’d have ample proof of

we couldget into her rooms in Fittes House, we’d have ample proof of it, I bet. he said. “If we get Barnes in, Winkman’s men will just melt away and wait it out until hisback’s turned. Always uncomfortable with a roofover her head, she had even less inclination to stay with the possibility of an attackplanned. Before departure, however, Lockwood took her to the library. They spoke therefor a long time, alone. Then Flo slipped away, leaving only a few dirty footprints in thehall for us to remember her by. We continued making improvements to our barricades.Mid-morning came, and there was activity at Arif’s Stores. Two men were seen to gointo the shop, where they purchased newspapers. With these under their arms, theymigrated to opposite sides of the street and sat on walls there, one in shadow, one baskingin the autumn sun. Thickset and silent, they read their papers and smoked cigarettes;otherwise, they were as one with the bricks and the concrete. He rubbed his neck with careful fingers.“Not specific enough. We need at least five A-class chains of 50mm width. If we go out now, those bozos down the street will killus. Can’t we use two B-class ones?”​“Yeah, we can,” George said, “if you want a host of phantoms breaking out andsurrounding you in your sleeping bag tonight.”​“It’ll make a nice change from your snores, anyway,” Kipps said. He went away.​“Plus we need the B-class ones for the cross-chain.” George was studying somecrumpled plans on his lap. Since his appearance in the kitchen that morning, he andLockwood had been in deep

Since his appearance in the kitchen that morning, he andLockwood had been in deep discussions, and the plans were the result. “I’m still trying tofigure out how we can suspend it in mid-air. What do we fix it to?”​“Lockwood says we’ll just hammer posts into the ground. Like Rotwell did.”​“Rotwell wasn’t building his Gate in an upstairs bedroom,” George said. “What if theceiling falls in?” He sighed. “I still think we need more chains.”​He was full of little worries like that, George, which was understandable, given wewere working to his design. He had based it on our memories of the Gate constructed atthe Rotwell Institute earlier that year – the one through which Lockwood and I had

travelled in our first visit to the Other Side. The Rotwell team had done everything on amassive scale, with a double set of giant chains forming the circle, and a suspended ironchain (which crossed the circle) making the way in. Use a ribbon instead, or a bit of string.”​I rolled my eyes and stepped into the bedroom, bracing myself as always for theimpact of the death-glow, the pulses of cold energy that burned my skin and set my teethon edge. We were clearing the room out of everything that was inessential. It waslike looking into the fresh, clear waters of a mountain lake.“Oh, it’s lovely,” I said.“Yes, a sapphire. My father got it out east somewhere, and he had this made for mymother. It was her favourite thing. That’s what my sister told me once, anyway.”Lockwood took the box back and shut it up. “I didn’t know it was here.”“So your mum didn’t have it on her when she—?”“I don’t think she wore it in the ordinary way. That ropey stuffed bird in the case on the topshelf in the library? That was from him. And that dodgy gourd in the hall.”“I suspect she preferred the brooch,” I said.“Me too.” He put the box in his pocket. “What were you saying?”“George says we need more chains. But that means going out.”“Oh, that’s not a problem. I need to nip out anyway, do a few things. Tell you what,why don’t you come with me? Winkman’s men won’t attack us in broad daylight, thoughthey might try to follow us, see where we go. We’ll lose them, if so. Come on, let’s tellthe others

lose them, if so. Come on, let’s tellthe others what we plan to do.” Not long after lunch, Lockwood and I left the house and set off down Portland Row. Wewalked nonchalantly, rapiers gleaming in the sunshine. As we passed Arif’s Stores, twomen who had been sitting on opposite walls reading their newspapers abandoned thisactivity and began following us at a distance. We walked to Marylebone Station, whereanother man, sitting at a café table below the iron ghost-wards, put his coffee down andsauntered into the ticket halls behind us. All three men waited while we bought our fares;they themselves had tickets ready, and passed through the barriers close behind.​We took a southbound train to Oxford Circus. The train was fairly empty. The threemen rode in the next carriage along.Lockwood said: “All we have to do is shake them. If we go to Bond Street, they’llthink we’re going to Mullet’s. With luck we can double back while they’re still makingthat assumption.” He nudged me. “I’ve never had to lose a tail like this. It’s almost fun.”The brown shapes of the men were visible through the partition window at the end of

the carriage. Flo.”The train set off into the tunnel. We stood in the central aisle, holding the ceilinggrips, being gently moved from side to side.​“What?” I said. What?” That last one was thekind of ‘What?’ that made fellow passengers look up at us from where they sat. and wedged herself behind it in a corner of the room. She spent the night there, beside thebodies of her companions, fending off repeated attacks by the Visitors. You know whatLimbless are like. But it changed her.”​The train was slowing; we were coming into the next station. “Too right it did,” Isaid. “It made her cracked in the head.”​“That’s not altogether true and you know it.” Lockwood was looking up at the tubemap above the doors. “Anyway, I helped her out, in the difficult early months. Do youthink we lost them?”​“I didn’t see them getting on.”​“Nor did I. Good. This is Swiss Cottage. Right, we’ll split up here. Go get the chains.I’ll meet you on Primrose Hill in an hour.” On Primrose Hill, the park stretches down a long grass slope, and you have a clear viewsouth over London. I waited for Lockwood on a bench near the top, the new chains lyingbeside me in the grass. Below, the shadows of trees stretched out across the lawns. Fromthe west a spreading pinkness tinged the rooftops and bled like watercolour across thepale blue sky.It was that final flourish before the light began to fade and the city withdrew intoitself. Children ran past with hoops, played with footballs, roller skates. Couples pushedprams; you could hear the tinkling of their ghost-wards rising up the hill. Adult officeworkers, dawdling on their way home, bought cups of tea from vendors; the first night-watch kids leaned their sticks against the trees and played football or ate ice creamsbefore their shift.Lockwood came striding up the path, dark and thin and lit to shining by the sun. Itwas like he was going to ignite. For some reason the sight made me want to cry. He flunghimself onto the bench beside me, and looked out at the view.“Made your calls?” I said.“Yes. You got the chains?”“Yep.”“Excellent. We’d better be heading back, then.”“Lockwood,” I said. “I’m so sorry about your parents. I’ve been meaning to say this,but there’s been no time. Everything’s moving too fast.”Lockwood was sitting with hands resting in his lap. There was a sense of perfectpeace about him. About how theywere killed.”“You don’t need to be sorry, Luce.” He gazed out at the sunset, at the red stainspreading over London. “I’m not. It’s the best news I’ve had in a long time.”After a moment’s blankness, I couldn’t help grinning at him. kept surprising me.“Obviously I was shocked at first,” he went on, “but not now. Remember when we satin the cemetery, at my parents’ grave? idea I’d always had of him, the picture I saw in my mind’s eye when drawing near tosleep. The watchers were back outside 32 Portland Row, two shaven-headed men standingsullenly on the pavement opposite as we pushed open the iron gate and walked up thetiled path. I gave them a little wave. We unlocked the old black door and went inside.​The hall had that odd, cold, slightly echoing quality that you usually get when you’removing house. The air smelt of sawdust and chain oil. The chipped pot had a couple ofumbrellas in it, but no rapiers, which were now part of our defensive armoury. Theshelves were bare of their usual ornaments, and the coat rack had been ripped off thewall. Everything had been taken upstairs.​In Jessica’s room, all the furniture, except for the bed, had been removed, and the teachests and other boxes were gone too, broken up and used as barricades downstairs. Thebed itself, with its death-glow still pulsing fiercely, had been pulled towards the centre ofthe room. was sitting on the landing.“They’ve just put a Javanese back-scratcher and a witchdoctor’s second-hand chamber-pot in the circle, while totally ignoring my very clear signals to chuck them both away.”​“We haven’t got time to be picky,” I said. “It’ll be dark soon. Everything with theslightest shred of power is going in.”Lockwood and I hurried to join the work. I helped with the artefacts. our little group of agents at number 32 would be alone.As we ate a hurried meal, the skull in the jar made so many loud attempts to speakwith me that I closed the tap in its bung just to get some peace. bored a couple of spy-holes in the planks, and every now and then got up to look through them at the garden.You could just see the apple tree, the garden wall, the shapes and lights of other houses.The night was still. ​“We’re always fine.”​Without waiting for her response I got up, leaned over the sink and peered throughthe nearest spy-hole. my rapier out through the nearest spy-hole. Who knows the quickest way to the Strand?”  ​21. It was Portland Row. But it wasn’t Portland Row, not with that ferocious, never-endingsilence, and the frost on the road, and the roofs and chimney pots merging with that dullblack starless sky. The houses were architecturally the same, with adornments that Irecognised from walking past a thousand times. Oddities of design were replicated onindividual buildings – from porches to loft extensions to distinctive patterns in thebrickwork – but the dull, dead light that shone over everything and came from nowhere(there was no moon) rendered them flat and lifeless, as if drawn on giant slabs of card.There was something false about those buildings. You felt that if you knocked themwith your fist, whole walls would topple down. And their doors and windows weren’tright. The doors were either absent or ajar. They were gaping holes torn in the fabric ofthe street. None of the windows had curtains: all were stark and blank and staring. Itmade you feel things might be watching you from inside the empty rooms.  We walked down the centre of the street, huddled together, boots crunching the hard,white frost. A faint set of marks stretched ahead of us – the wandering footprints of asolitary man. We followed them as far as the empty shell of Arif’s Stores, where the wideshop windows hung blank and open, with mist swirling deep inside the carcass of thehouse. Here the footprints veered away along a side street and were lost to sight. We didnot follow them. If it had been Winkman we had seen, he had taken his own road. Hisway was not our way.Kipps adjusted a drooping feather on his hood,

Hisway was not our way.Kipps adjusted a drooping feather on his hood, so that he could see us. Blooms of icecrusted the lenses of his goggles. “We should go left here,” he whispered. “Cross PortlandStreet, take Regent Street, then cut through Soho. That’s the shortest route.”“Good.” Lockwood’s face was pinched, as if with remembered pain. I felt it too:already something pressed upon my spirits, a relic of my last walk in that freezing world.“We need to cut it short as we can,” he said. “And above all, avoid being noticed.” Helooked up at the black windows all around. “If that’s remotely possible…”We started off again, following Kipps’s directions. It wasn’t pleasant to walk too

close to the open doors, but it wasn’t nice being out in the middle of the street either. Thatleft us feeling exposed. Despite the mist that coiled around us, despite our hushed voicesand the stealth with which we took each step, we knew our very presence made usvulnerable. We did not belong there. We were too solid, too colourful, too alive to bemistaken for an inhabitant of that dark city. If they saw us, those inhabitants would knowthat very well.​But to begin with we saw nobody at all.There were no ghost-lamps, no railings, no cars, nothing of iron, and no runningwater. The drains and gutters were empty, the runnels dry. Street nameplates had gone,and the signs above the store fronts carried no legible words. The way we took wasfamiliar to us, but the overarching silence made it alien. I’d been exposed to stillness likethis when I’d crossed over at Aldbury Castle, but that journey had been in the open andempty countryside. Here, in central London, the utter silence had a transformative effect.It turned the rows of houses into cliff faces, the streets into a dark labyrinth of canyonsand ravines. When you drew close to the buildings, you saw that the brickwork wasbrittle and cracked; on some corners whole sections had eroded away, leaving vast holeslike a giant’s bite-marks in the walls.The air was bitter-cold, a dry, dead absence that sucked the life from your lungs andthe motion from your blood. It clung to the surface of our cloaks, coating them with icethat creaked and cracked gently as we moved. But it could not penetrate. Whether madeby long-dead witchdoctors, who had sewn my spirit cape out of silver thread and birdfeathers, or by the modern day fanatics of the Orpheus Society, who had aped this artwith silver flakes and iron wire, the cloaks performed their function well. We existed infragile bubbles of warmth that sustained us as we hurried on. We were standing at the corner ofWeymouth Street and Portland Place, on a sloping pile of frost-blown bricks, taking stockof the next abandoned road.
