He’d been moving slowest of all ofus, and we’d had to rein in our pace to stay with him.“Best not look at anything,” I said. “Don’t look, don’t think. Just keep going.”Lockwood returned from the corner, where he’d been spying out the broad expanse ofPortland Place. He met my gaze and smiled, but you could see the effort it took, and theanxiety in his eyes. “The next street seems empty,” he said, “though there are several setsof footprints crossing it. Don’t know if that means someone’s been here recently or not.Prints here might last a long time.”“Do we risk it?” I said. “It’s very open.”“Yes, but it’s direct. I don’t see it’s any worse than going a narrow way.”“And there’s no one there?” Holly said.

there’s no one there?” Holly said. “You’re sure?”“As far as I can see.” Lockwood shrugged. “I’ve got to say, I’m surprised we’ve notseen anyone yet. We’re lucky.”​Lucky was one way of putting it. When Lockwood and I had walked in such a worldbefore, the inhabitants had been drawn to us like summer flies to rotting fruit. We wouldtake the emptiness while it lasted. So we turned down Portland Place, where the misthung low between the hotel fronts like the waters of a white lagoon. The dull blank lightthat had no source lit both sides of the street the same: there was no sun, no north orsouth, no time and no direction.​As Lockwood had said, three or four lines of footprints, one clearly a little child’s,crossed the frosted street at intervals. With the mist and the half-light we couldn’t seewhere they had come from or where they were going.​“No one’s talking yet,” Holly said. “I know it might bring things after us, but I reallyneed us to chat a bit. Please, just a little.”

​“Okay, I’m game.” George spoke with forced jollity; he was the weakest of us,finding it hardest to move. He put his arm through Holly’s. “Did I ever tell you my theoryabout why the dead followed Lucy and Lockwood that time?” he asked. “See, whenVisitors come to our world, they bring with them all sorts of stuff to mess our senses –foul miasmas, chill, creeping dread, you name it. Mostly, that means we know they’rearound before they even show. Well, why wouldn’t it be the same in reverse? We’reintruders here. Who’s to say we don’t carry all kinds of unsettling scents with us?”​“You certainly do, George,” Kipps put in. “It’s a plausible theory.”​“Thanks.”​“When we get through all of this,” I said. “I mean, when we expose Marissapublically for what she is, I’d like to take a holiday. I want to go to the countryside,where there are hills and streams and not many ghosts, and stay awhile there. Anyonewith me on that? We could rent a cottage, just the five of us—”​“Five? What about Flo?” George said.​“Oh, okay, she could come as long as she took a bath. Then we’d go for walks andsee things, and sort of hang around and do nothing. And then we’d come back to PortlandRow and get back to work, but only do the jobs we really liked. And George, everyonewould want to know about our cases, so you could write them up properly and get thempublished in a—”​“Lucy,” Lockwood said, “shut up a minute.”​He had been walking slightly in front, alert and questioning, head moving always sideto side. Now he stopped and pointed. There was a place ahead of us where the officebuildings sat back from the centre of the street. In the frosted square of concrete thuscreated, a group of people was standing. They had their backs to us, and the mist wasthick around them, but we could see that they were men and women and children, dressedin a great variety of styles. They weren’t still, but shuffling and moving about with everyappearance of disquiet, and the focus of their attention was something dark that hungbehind them, black but also shimmering.I thought at first it was a door, though the shape wasn’t right; then I thought it was ahole in the wall of the building, but that wasn’t right either – the darkness seemedseparate from the wall, and somehow closer, and a corner of it kind of overlapped awindow behind. The figures were making a great effort to get closer to this darkness, butwere deterred by an object that I couldn’t quite identify. It looked a bit like one of oursilver nets, only it was much bigger, and supported by poles, so that it resembled a littlefence. White flecks hung twitching and fluttering on the net. As we watched, one of thefigures, impelled by strong compulsion, broke free of the crowd and threw itself againstthe silver net. There was a soft sound, a flash of light; the figure was gone. New whitefronds hung twitching from the net and the crowd stirred with agitation.​“Come on,” Lockwood whispered. “If we’re quick, we can get past them.”​Pressing close to the other side of the road, we made off down a narrow side street,looking behind us all the while. No one followed us and we soon slowed our pace, for wewere very weary. Weary – and perplexed, for now a new mystery hung over us. That darkspace preyed on my mind. Though it would have been fatal to draw the attention of thatsilent crowd, I had experienced a strong and unaccountable urge

of thatsilent crowd, I had experienced a strong and unaccountable urge to draw near to it. I thinkthe others felt the same. Without Lockwood, I think all of us would have been slow tomove away.​We crossed a grey and empty Oxford Street not far from the great junction of OxfordCircus, where another crowd of figures, larger than the first, milled and churned around.Again I glimpsed a flash of silver, a vertical patch of darkness rising at the heart of thethrong. One or two solitary persons could be seen advancing along the street towards us,and we did not dawdle now, but hurried down into Soho, where the streets were narrower,the buildings older, and hollow shells of houses pressed close beside the road.​My limbs were heavy, my breath rasped at the back of my mouth. Tiny cold flamesdanced across the hood of Holly’s cloak, and twists of vapour rose from our ice-bound

capes, stretching us in a long and telltale trail.​With every step and every street now, the way became difficult. Many of the cracksthat ran through the fabric of the buildings extended out into the roads, causing greatslabs of frozen tarmac to sheer up randomly like shark fins in the swirling mist. Therewas noticeably more activity around us now too; shambling figures seen in side-roads,hunched presences in upstairs room. Several times we had to make abrupt changes ofdirection when something appeared in the mist ahead of us. Kipps led the way now. Mystrength was seeping out of me, and the others were also failing fast, but he appeared tohave had a burst of energy. At each crossroads he took to going ahead, scouting the way,while the rest of us gathered our breath.​“You all right, Lucy?” Lockwood fell in step beside me. Holly was just ahead,supporting the limping George.​“I’m feeling it now,” I said. “It’s getting hard. And there are more of them around.”​“Maybe more people have died here. I don’t know.”“And Lockwood…”​His lips had a dusting of ice. “Yes?”​“Did you see them? Those dark spaces…”​He didn’t speak, but only nodded. I knew the weight he felt; it lay on my heart too.​“Did you see the spirits, clustering round?”​“I saw them.”“Like they were doors to move through?”A shrug was his only answer. He was right, in a way, not to want to talk about it. Ourbusiness led us elsewhere. And neither of us wanted to re-enforce the tug we’d felt, whenwe’d looked at the strange dark voids. It was the tug you get on a crumbling cliff-top,when you’re tempted to step close, lean over, and look down.​At the next junction, Kipps went ahead again. We watched him dart along the grey-black street, his boots sending up tiny clouds of frost. Halfway along he flitted suddenlyinto the shelter of a shop porch. We waited; moments later one of the inhabitants of DarkLondon came out of a nearby house, moved across the street and vanished in the shadowsbeyond, passing just a few feet away from Kipps without noticing him.When all was clear, Kipps peeled himself from the shadows and moved on. Presentlyhe came to the next crossing, where he looked in all directions before signalling us tofollow.“You’re in good shape, Quill,” I whispered, when we caught up with him.Kipps nodded. “I feel great. Must be the effect of this coat or something.”“How’s the side? Not giving you any trouble?”He gave a shrug; he was already staring up the next street, eyes bright, eager to begone. “It’s funny. In that last second in the bedroom, just before going through, I thoughtGale’s blade had really caught me. And it did hurt a bit at first, but it’s really calmeddown now. Can’t feel it at all.”“Great. I’m glad.”“You struggling?” Kipps asked me, after a pause. “You look tired.”“It’s the cold,” I said. “And the silence. I don’t think it does any of us much good,even with the capes on.”We looked at the others. They were slumped at the corner, where the pavement’scracks had become so distorted that great sections had erupted like broken wheel spokes,projecting into the black sky. Their heads were down, they stared dully from under theirfrosted hoods; evidently they shared my

they stared dully from under theirfrosted hoods; evidently they shared my feeling of oppression.“Even Lockwood’s taking a breather,” Kipps said. He chuckled. “Not often I’ve gotmore of a spring in my step than him.” He stood up, gazing down the cold and silentroad. “Well, don’t worry. It’s not long to go now. We should take Windmill Street andcross Shaftesbury Avenue at this point. I don’t think there’s much going on down there.”​“You mean… inhabitants?”​“Right. There are some, but it feels less busy than further up, even though it’s a

slightly longer distance to The Strand. You others ready?” he called. “I thought youwanted to do this fast.”Almost without waiting for them to struggle to their feet, he was off again, nimble,light-footed, our self-appointed guide. And as Kipps said, Windmill Street did lookmostly empty. He was gone so quickly I didn’t have a chance to ask him how he knew.​Our cloaks were steaming thickly now, leaving a vapour plume that trailed behind us,coilingly persistent on the still, dead air. I disliked this trail. It was my habit to lookbehind me, check nothing was following in our track. At last, when I did so, I saw that wehad company. Some way behind us, a thin man had come out of one of the narrowhouses; he wore a pale brown suit and an old-fashioned, broad-brimmed hat. Ourfootprints passed right in front of him, and I had a suspicion that our trail of vapour didalso. He didn’t look at us. He stood staring straight out into the road like he wasclockwork and his key had just wound down.​“Trouble behind us,” I muttered.Everyone looked. Holly’s voice was hoarse and high. “What do we do?”“Just keep walking,” Lockwood said, “and take the next turning.”The mists ahead of us swirled and parted. At the intersection up ahead, a group offigures stood near one of the shimmering black doors, which had again been closed off bya silver net. There were men there, women, children. They blocked the road.Lockwood cursed. “Quick! In here.” He darted to the wall on our left, where an alleyopened, a slot between buildings. We followed him in, ploughed down it. It was thenarrowest of gaps. Bricks brushed my cape on either side; fear gnawed at me in case itwould be ripped, as another cape had once been. I drew my shoulders in. The alleybecame narrower and narrower, I felt that I would be pressed to nothing. All at once itturned sharply to the right and opened into a tiny yard.High brick walls towered over us on three sides. In one of them, at head height, was arectangular opening – a door that in our world was perhaps reached by iron stairs. Therewere no other doors, and no routes through.  “Hell,” Lockwood panted. “Dead end.”“What do we do?” Kipps wasn’t breathing hard. “There’s a door up there.”“We can’t go inside a building, it’s not safe. We wait. If he didn’t spot us, that singleguy will drift off eventually. We can go back, take another way.”“I don’t think he noticed us,” I said. “What do you think, Holly?”​“I think he did.”​I stared at her. “Yeah…” I said slowly, “I do too.”​We stood in the yard, with black brick walls around us, and the alley’s aperture theblackest strip of all. Time passed; by and by we heard faint sounds coming from the gap,as of bare feet scuffing along it on hard ground.​“Door,” Kipps said. “It’s the only way. I’ll give you a shin up.”“Yes—” Lockwood was already beside him at the wall, clasping his hands ready.“Quick, Hol. You too, Luce.”Neither Holly or I had to be told twice. I gave a little run-up – or as close to a run as Icould manage with my deadened limbs, stepped onto Kipps’s hands and was propelledupwards with surprising strength onto the ledge. Lockwood launched Holly alongside.We slipped and struggled,

the ledge. Lockwood launched Holly alongside.We slipped and struggled, and got in each other’s way, but in moments stood in the opendoorway. George, heavier and stiffer, was harder work; Kipps and Lockwood had tocombine forces to propel him to the ledge, where Holly and I bundled him through thedoor. Lockwood moved back a few paces and was vaulted up by Kipps’s hand. ThenLockwood, Holly and I reached out, grabbed Kipps’s arms and dragged him bodily up thewall.We were just pulling him alongside us when the thin man with the broad-brimmed hatshuffled into the yard.“Can he get up here?” I said.We stood in the doorway looking down at the man. He stood looking up at us, withbone-white face, and dark unblinking eyes.He started to walk towards our wall.“Tell you what,” Kipps said, “let’s assume he can. Come on – these old Soho houses

are a maze. We can cut through here and out into another street quick as anything. Followme.”He drew his sword, briefly surveyed the passage ahead of us, then plunged along it,deep into the building. We hesitated. If the hall in Portland Row had been unpleasant towalk down, this was no better. The proportions of the corridor felt wrong, and iceglistened in fissures by the ceiling. There was a sour taint on the air.  Fingertips scrabbled at the wall behind us.You know, that passage looked just fine. We stumbled after Kipps as fast as we couldgo.My memory of what followed has the jumbled quality of a dream. We went downcorridors, up staircases, into rooms that led nowhere, doubling back the way we’d come,expecting always to come face to face with what pursued us. We went through endlessdoors, some ordinary, others thick with ice and twisted into odd dimensions. All wereopen – no doors were locked in the dark, cold world. You could go anywhere, butnowhere was any better than anywhere else, and we could not find the way out of thebuilding. Sometimes we passed windows, but either they were too high, or too narrow, orso caked with frost that we could not see out from them to know if it was safe to jump.There was nothing but the scrape of our boots on the wooden floors, and our breath likebroken pistons, and the flap and flutter of Kipps’s feathers just ahead. And somewherebehind, feet following.He was right: those old houses were a maze. We passed through attics, where faintoutlines of dolls’ houses and rocking horses merged with spreading shadows; throughrooms where beds seemed half sunken into the tilted floors; through kitchens, where darkobjects hung dead and heavy from ceiling hooks; up rattling staircases that grew widethen thin with every twist or turn; and once, out on a high parapet that ran betweenbuildings, with the white street far below and ice shards tumbling soundlessly beneathour skidding boots. That street unnerved us, and not because of our height: a host of greyfigures stood in it, looking up as we ran like rats into the house beyond.And now there began to be noises from neighbouring rooms, as if things kept pacewith us beyond the walls. Kipps was cursing now, moving ever faster, shying away fromopen corridors, squeezing through cracks, dropping through chutes of ice and rubble; andall the while Lockwood brought up the rear, rapier out, steadily retreating, staring backthe way we had come.And then, all at once, we came into a room where a small child sat. It had a pudding-bowl haircut and was sitting cross-legged by an empty chimney hearth. It looked for allthe world that it was reading, but there was no book in the little hands, and the stool orchair that it had sat on was long gone too. It floated in mid-air, forlorn and self-sufficient,and there was something so pitiful about it that we couldn’t help but pause.Beside it was something else: a narrow fissure, filled with light. It was hard to tellwhether it was on the floor or just hanging in mid-air. As with so much to do with theOther Side, you saw it best when you weren’t looking at it directly, but there wassomething about the quality of the shimmer that made my heart leap with longing.Because it was not of the Other Side, it was not of this place at all.​“It’s a Source,” George croaked. “It’s where that Visitor goes through.”“Back to our world,” Holly whispered. “Look at the light…”Trust me, I was looking. “Could we—?”“No!” Kipps said. “It’s too small. It’s too small! Come on! We can’t stay here!”

It’s too small! Come on! We can’t stay here!” Hepulled us towards the door.​“He’s right,” Lockwood said in a hoarse voice. “They’re close behind.”George groaned. “That guy can’t be still following us?”Lockwood grimaced, showing his teeth. “Him and the rest. I’ve counted at least four.”​And then we were out of the room, down another flight of steps with a long corridorstretching in front, and saw (it was almost as welcome as that flash of real living light),an open arch that gave us a glimpse of frosted pavement and open air.​“There!” Holly said.We burst out through the arch and halted, wheezing, gasping, particles of ice fallingfrom our capes. Exhaustion overcame us, then. We had no strength to carry on. Whichwas a pity in that particular road, because we weren’t alone. It was crowded with a hostof London’s dead. Silent, pale and moving fast, they swarmed towards us along the street.

We pressed our backs to the wall.    ​22. “Don’t say anything,” Lockwood hissed. “Don’t move.”​As all-time unnecessary suggestions went, it was way up there. We made like fivestatues, lined up by the door. Breathing wasn’t high on our agenda, let alone movement. Iwas pressing so hard against the bricks I thought I’d probably push right through. Myheart was banging like a bass drum in my ears; it beat so loud in the awful silence I feltsure the ranks of rushing figures would at once change direction and throw themselves onme.​There was sizeable company of them, twenty figures at least, adults mostly, butchildren too. They were passing along the centre of the road, neither walking nor exactlyrunning, but hurrying forth in a kind of stumbling lope. Their clothes were bleached ofcolour, their faces in dark shadow; there was nothing strong or definite about them,except the glittering of their eyes. But they pulled a cloud of longing and unhappiness intheir wake, and it swept against me in a great cold wave. The company came within a fewfeet of us, making no noise except for the faintest flapping of their thin, cold garments,and swept away along the road.​We prised ourselves carefully clear of the wall; in those few seconds frost had alreadybegun bonding our capes to the surface. Kipps brushed his feathers down. “What, aren’twe worth killing any more?” he said. “I feel a little hurt.”​​“Something’s attracting them,” I whispered. I was looking along the street where thewandering spirits had gone. Between the houses I could see a thin grey line, straight as apine tree, rising stark against the pitch-black sky. “Something’s drawing them on.”​Lockwood drew his cloak tighter and stepped off the pavement. “Let’s go and seewhat it is.”​It was the way we had to go, for the thin grey line was Nelson’s Column, and the roadsoon opened into the great expanse of Trafalgar Square. Not far beyond this lay theStrand – and Fittes House, our final destination. But all thought of that was for themoment blotted out by what we saw in the centre of the square.​In our world, the open plaza beneath the column was often the site of demonstrationsby people protesting at new curfews, or other restrictions caused by the Problem. In this,at least, dark London was no different, for a great congregation of the dead was gatheredthere. It was a host large enough to effortlessly absorb the little group that had just passedby us. I could not begin to count them all.The mass of spirits was pressing in on a low, fenced structure ranged around the footof the column. These fences were formed of silver mesh, similar to the ones we’d seenblocking off the strange dark apertures at Oxford Circus and elsewhere. Within thecompound a small number of men and women in silver clothes were moving. Even froma distance it was clear that they were living. They had a different quality to the horde ofgrey forms beyond the barrier; they were far more solid, the hues of their outfits morevibrant and real. They bustled about with focused, purposeful movements, and faintmetallic clanks and clattering drifted towards us on the still, dead air.There was something jarring about the noise and the colour and the sense of purpose,something brash and inappropriate in that sombre place. Looking at them, I recognisedfor the first time how wrong it was that we were there.They did not wear cloaks, but long tunics hanging over loose trousers. They had lighthelmets, and goggles similar the ones Kipps wore. They moved casually, absorbed intheir work. This consisted of tending to racks of glass cylinders, stacked near the foot ofNelson’s Column. Some of the smaller
stacked near the foot ofNelson’s Column. Some of the smaller cylinders appeared to have something inside;

workers were carefully decanting them into bigger ones, which were then lined up nearthe gate to the enclosure.The proximity of the dead did not disturb them. One of the group (a woman, Ithought) patrolled the inside of the fence with a device on a long pole. It had some kindof silver tip. Occasionally, in a bored sort of way, she thrust it outside to touch one of thespirits who got too close, sending it darting back into the crowd.A man emerged from an iron hut at the centre of the compound. He wore stilts similarto the ones the Orpheus secretary had used and had a large cylinder strapped to his back.As we watched, he slipped out of the compound and waded waist-high through the massof swarming dead, who rippled backwards they sought to evade painful touch of silver.Some weren’t quick enough; we could hear the hiss and squeal of bursting plasm. Theman strode onwards, outstripping those spirits who tried to follow him, and disappearedthrough the mists in the direction of the Strand.We watched for a short time. Then Lockwood drew us close.​“Want to know the cause of the Problem?” he whispered. “This is it, right here.”​Holly brushed ice from the sleeves of her steaming cloak. “What are those idiotsdoing?”“Apart from stirring up the dead, you mean?” George said. He was squinting over thetop of his glasses; they were thoroughly frosted over, but he hadn’t the strength to wipethem. “See those cylinders? Bet they contain ectoplasm. Or essence, or whatever otherfancy name you want to call it.” He gestured towards the Strand. “This is how she gathersit. I’ll bet she gets it from those nets hung up around town.”“It’s not just Marissa that’s in on this,” Kipps added. “The Sunrise Corporation makesthe cylinders. You can see their logo from here.”“Yes, there’s a whole industry going on here,” Lockwood said. “The one good thing iswe’re surely right to think we’ll find a Gate at Fittes House. Well, we can’t stop or we’llfreeze to death. My bones are like ice as it is. Let’s go and end it now.”​It was fortunate for us that the activity in the square monopolised the attention of boththe living and the dead. We did not have the strength to do anything but shuffle, by thequickest, shortest route, to the mouth of the Strand. We kept as close to the buildings onthe perimeter as we could; once we had to duck inside the shell of a blackened, frost-blown church as something on silver legs passed by. Otherwise, we were undisturbed.Soon we stood on the steps outside Fittes House, with mists and desolation stretchingeither side.  ​And it was the place, all right. There was no room for doubt. The frost on the stepshad been worn away by the passage of many feet, and a silver net hung suspended in theopen door to keep the wandering dead at bay. It hung there like a portcullis, or a range ofjagged teeth. Above it, the bones of the building rose many storeys to merge with theblack sky.​“Got to risk it,” Lockwood croaked. “We might meet someone coming in or out, butwe can’t help that now. It’s been too long. Must be hours since we came through thecircle.”​Kipps had darted up the steps to peer into the interior. “Looks clear. There are lampsburning to show the way. Want me to go ahead, scan the route?”​“No. We’ll all go. We can’t waste time.”​​​It was a strange thing, entering that dark echo of Fittes House. What a contrast it

strange thing, entering that dark echo of Fittes House. What a contrast it waswith the grandiose and busy version that I knew. In our world, the entrance hall wasabuzz with business at all hours, ranks of cool receptionists attending to queues ofprospective clients; successful applicants reading magazines in comfy sofas; a smallstatue of Marissa Fittes blandly watching over all. Here, it was a black and empty room,like a cavern in a slate mine, with low-slung roof and wet ice on the floor. In places, ironsupports had been brought in to keep the ceiling from falling in. A few cracked cylindersand plastic oil cans lay in the shadows.There was no statue of Marissa. Somewhere deeper in this house lurked the real thing.​Glimmering oil lanterns had been arranged at intervals, marking the safe route intothe building. It was a necessary measure: in certain places the floor had fallen away

completely, or the ceiling had collapsed under the weight of ice. The walls bowedinwards; floors slanted. I began to experience the same claustrophobia I’d felt at PortlandRow.    ​We followed the line of lanterns, and soon came to the Hall of Pillars – or its dark anddismal counterpart. Here, disconcertingly, the nine trapped spirits stood, faint andflickering. They watched us avidly as we passed, rotating to keep pace with us. Pin-pricksof light burned in their hollow eyes. Long Hugh Henratty, the highwayman whose ghosthad been one of the first captured by Marissa and Tom Rotwell, grinned lopsidedly abovehis broken neck. The Clapham Butcher Boy made urgent motions with his spectral knife.Fortunately the silver-glass pillars on the other side held firm.All nine called out to us in soft voices, hooting and crying like owls. The words werenot pleasant. I’m used to such stuff, but it disturbed the others more than me, for to theirsurprise they found they could hear them too.We left the room in haste, and so came to the Hall of Dead Heroes, where lift shaftsaccessed other floors. In our world, lavender fires burned perpetually here beside theshrines to fallen agents. There were no shrines here, just a black void. The three shaftswere likewise gaping holes, filled with mist. The lanterns led us past them, and presentlywe came to a staircase leading down.​“The Gate must be on a basement level,” Lockwood said. “Well, we expected that.”He mustered a frozen smile. “This is the last push, everyone. Stay strong. We’re almostthere.”​Down we went, flight after flight; and the lanterns led us ever deeper into the earth.We went very slowly now, past openings to unknown levels. On the third floor down, wesaw a light coming towards us through the dark.​“Quick! Off the steps!” Lockwood pulled us back into a side room, its mouth part-filled with rubble; here we crouched, as far back as we dared, watching as the globe oflight drew nearer along a passage, and burned the mouth of the stairs into drab, grey life.  ​It was two tall figures walking side by side. We watched them as in a dream. Theyhad their heads bent, close together; there was the murmur of conversation. The first worea silver cloak with a sweeping hood. Her long dark hair was pulled back almost out ofsight, but the graceful lines of the face were clear enough. It was the woman we knew asboth Penelope and Marissa, and she was laughing at something her companion said.This other person was a fair-haired young man, very tall and handsome. He wore akind of shimmering robe, which somehow reminded me of the negligible dresses LaBelle Dame had once been prone to wear: glitzy, glamorous, and not at all extensive. Itssole purpose seemed to be to highlight the impressive muscle tones of the young man’storso, his athletic arms and legs, the swaying way his body moved. He had an exquisite beauty, and you could tell all this because he lacked both cloak and silver tunic. Hewalked through the dark and frozen world without protection, and a faintly goldenradiance hung about him. Indeed it was this light that we’d seen from afar.The woman strode to the head of the stairs and was just taking the flight down whenthe young man touched her arm. He stood there, gazing all about him.“What is it?” Penelope (or Marissa) said.“I smell something living.” The young man cocked his head; he wrinkled his elegantnose.“It’ll be the night crew. They’ve just started a shift. You know how the trace lingers.”“Even so…” He looked towards the side-room where we

so…” He looked towards the side-room where we crouched in darkness.She shook her head. “I need to get back. There’s some kind of trouble on the sunlitside.”The young man made no further comment. They swept away down the staircase. Theglow of other-light faded in the stairwell and the half-dark swallowed us again.“What was that?” Holly whispered. “Did you see him?” Her voice shook; my ownbody was trembling with cold too, as if the cloaks were wearing thin.“A spirit…” I said. “He was so beautiful.”​George spoke in cracked tones. “You think? Looked a bit over-ripe to me.”“Down!” Lockwood said; his voice was scarcely audible. “No matter what, we’ve gotto keep going down and find this wretched Gate.”

​It was all we could do to descend the last two flights, for our stamina was at an end.Twice, George nearly fell; his legs were giving out, and Kipps, who was the strongest ofus, had to grapple him under the arms and pull him onward. Holly and I supported eachother too. In this manner, fumbling, dishevelled and almost dead, we came at last to thefinal basement beneath Fittes House. The lanterns led through a dark and empty chambertowards an arch, and here at last I heard what I’d been straining for: the psychic thrumand tumult of a nearby Gate.  Lockwood sensed it too. He made a noise that in better times might have been a cryof triumph. We roused ourselves a final time and hobbled forwards.“And what time do you call this?” said a voice.We stopped dead in our tracks; we raised our hoods a little and looked stiffly round.“If I’d known you’d be this long, I’d have put my curlers in,” the thin youth said. Hewas standing far off across the room, half in and half out of a giant bulb of ice that hadrisen through the floor. His spiky hair gleamed with other-light; otherwise he was as faintand flickering and gleefully supercilious as ever.“Skull!” A wave of something washed through me. Relief? Pleasure at seeingsomething familiar in this dreadful place? Whatever it was, it made me warm. “I’m sohappy to see you,” I said, stumbling towards him. “How did you get here?”“Well, I’m not actually here, am I?” the youth said. “I’m still in my precious jar,sitting in a bright-lit laboratory storeroom below Fittes House, surrounded by cylindersof stolen essence, and with one or two rather faint-hearted scientists pottering by. Infact… hold on… yes, I’ve just scared one of them half to death by showing him the HappyFarmhand. And all while talking to you. Is that clever?” The youth grinned. “I ratherthink it is.”“But how did you—”“Lucy.” Lockwood shuffled alongside me, the others close behind. They were peeringat the youth in bafflement. For a moment, I couldn’t understand their confusion, then Irealised what it was: they could hear him.“This is the skull?” Lockwood frowned at him. “The skull’s… spirit? He… he looksdifferent.”The youth scowled. “Yeah? You look just the same. I was banking on frost-bite takinga few of your fingers, or even your nose. Here’ s hoping something else has dropped offthat I don’t know about. If not, I’m sorely disappointed.”Lockwood stared. “Does he always talk like this?”​“No. Usually he’s worse. See what I have to put up with now?”​“Oh, she likes it,” the youth said. “She can’t get enough of it. I cheer her up no end.”​“Cheer me up now,” I said, “and tell me quickly how you’re here – and what’s on theother side of the Gate. We’re going to come across now… if we can.”​“Shouldn’t be a problem if you’re quick,” the ghost said. “The lab technicians havejust gone for a coffee break. I think they were getting tired of all my faces. Well, I say it’ snot a problem. That’ s assuming you’ve got enough energy to survive the crossing.” It castits eyes over us. “Let’ s see – hangdog, lacklustre, clearly out

“Let’ s see – hangdog, lacklustre, clearly out on your feet. Great. Incracking form for a finale.”​“Don’t lump me in with these lightweights,” Kipps said.​“And Kipps…” The scrawny youth stared at him. “How are you feeling, then?”​Kipps blinked. “Me? Great. Why?”​“No reason.” The ghost’s image flickered out, then returned; it cast contemplativeeyes around the empty room. “I’ll keep it quick,” it said. “Sir Rupert Gale brought me toFittes House, to be ‘assessed’ or ‘processed’ or chucked in the Furnaces, whatever theywant to do. He brought me down here, and I’ve been sitting in this lab ever since, waitingfor you to show, watching a steady stream of madmen put on silly suits and pass back andforth to the Other Side. Marissa herself came past me just now; took off her cape andcaught a lift up top.” The youth pointed to a gaping lift-shaft in a corner of the room.“She was in a hurry. Didn’t stop to say hello.”​“Marissa came by?” Lockwood asked. “Was she alone?”

​“Hey, Lucy asks the questions round here,” the youth said. “You can’t just swan inand take over like you’re the leader or anything. Where’ s your respect?”​I cleared my throat. “Please, Skull, was Marissa on her own?”​“There – see, that’s how it’ s done.” The ghost smiled broadly at Lockwood. “Yes,Lucy, she was on her lonesome. Why?”​“It doesn’t matter,” I said. “We’ve got to follow her.” A thought occurred to me.“What time is it now, over there? Is it morning yet?” I had a sudden desperate yearning tosee the sun.​“Nope. Clock on the wall says just past midnight. Hours yet till dawn.”Lockwood spoke through cracked lips. “Wait! That can’t be true! Winkman and Galeraided Portland Row just after midnight. It’s got to be later than that.”“It is. Twenty-four hours later. I was brought here early morning, and a whole longday’ s gone by.” The youth grinned at us, and in that grin the face in the jar was clearlyvisible. “I said you’d been delayed.”Our faces had sagged. “Impossible,” Holly whispered. “We’d have known…”“That’s the thing about being technically dead,” the ghost said. “You lose all track oftime… ”There was no further hesitation; no one wanted to stay a moment more. The othersshuffled towards the arch. Only I hung back.“Thanks, Skull,” I said. “I’ll pick you up on the other side.”The youth nodded at me. “I hope you’ve still got your hammer with you. Oh, oneother thing. Kipps.”“What about him?”“Anything happen to him recently?”“No.”“Sure about that, are you?”Before I could answer, I heard Holly calling me urgently from the next room. Theyouth waved an indulgent hand; I limped as fast as I could across the room and throughthe arch.And in there was the Gate.In actual fact, calling it a ‘gate’ doesn’t really do it justice. It was more than that. Itwas a bridge, a checkpoint, a high-road for the living to pass through. George had beenright. Lockwood’s parents had been right. For years, hidden here, in this basement belowFittes House in the centre of London, there had been a permanent route between ourworld and the Other Side.It was a large room, lit by lanterns, and in the centre of it was a pit. The pit wascircular in shape and very broad, and it had a low wall built right around it. This wall,about the height of my knee, was made of solid iron. Thus, at a stroke, the Fittes agencyhad dispensed with the hassle and impermanence of iron chains. Although the precisecontents of the pit could not be seen, I knew it was stuffed with Sources, because thatfamiliar column of hazy light rose above it, packed with trapped and rushing spirit forms.To cross the pit, the designers hadn’t bothered with small-time stuff like hangingchains, as Rotwell (and we) had done. Instead, an iron walkway or bridge – thin, but verysolid – surmounted the wall and spanned the centre of the pit, before disappearing intothe swirling haze. I couldn’t see to the far side, but I knew that if we passed through it,we would be back in the living world.The others were waiting for me at the entrance to the bridge. I could scarcelyrecognise them beneath their crusted, steaming capes. Forget the spirits whirling in the pitbehind us. We were five shapeless

Forget the spirits whirling in the pitbehind us. We were five shapeless demons, made monstrous by our journey.“There’s just a chance someone will be in the room on the other side,” Lockwoodsaid. With stiff, hesitant movements, he drew his sword. “I’ll go first, with Holly. ThenGeorge. Kipps – you and Lucy follow on. No one hang back for anything.”He didn’t have energy for more, but turned and stepped onto the iron walkway. Youcould see him flinch as he approached the psychic maelstrom, but he did not stop. Hollyfollowed him. They moved up the walkway, shoulders bent, heads bowed, with theircloaks humped and frozen like tortoise-shells beneath their burdens of smoking ice. Oneither side, spirits moaned and chattered; pale arms reached out for them, but brokeasunder as they neared the strips of iron.

Lockwood and Holly passed over the centre of the pit. The haze closed round them,and they could no longer be seen.“Off you go, George,” Kipps said.George’s energy was almost spent. As he climbed onto the walkway, he tripped andfell. Kipps reached out an arm to catch him. As he did so, his coat of icy feathers swungaside, and I saw his tattered jersey below, with the rent in its side where Sir Rupert Gale’srapier had cut through. The fabric hung open, and I caught a single awful glimpse of thebloodless, gaping wound beneath.​The coat fell back into place. Kipps caught George, helped him get upright. He sethim on the walkway. George shuffled forwards.With a spring in his step, Kipps began to follow him.“Quill,” I said. “Hold on.”​He looked back at me. “What? Come on! This is what we’ve been waiting for! We’vegot to get out and at them!” His eyes were sparkling; he was grinning with the thrill of thechase. I’d never seen him so alive.​“Wait.” My voice was thick. “Don’t go through.”​He scowled. For a second it was the old Kipps, back again. “Why not? Don’t bestupid, Lucy.”​It wasn’t easy to talk, and not just because of the cold. “Why do you think you’refeeling so good here?” I said. “So… at home?”​He stared at me. “What? What nonsense are you talking about?”​“It’s just. Just. Quill, that injury you got…”He gave his little barking laugh. “When you say ‘at home’, Lucy, it’s almost likeyou’re saying—” His eyes held mine, and then he understood. The light slowly went outof them, like a flower closing. His face was a pale mask. Then he lifted up his cape and,ignoring the steaming, cracking ice that fell from the feathers, looked underneath it at hisshadowed side. He didn’t move for a while. He let the feathers drop back into position.He nodded once, very slowly, as if to himself. He didn’t look at me.“Well,” he said.“Oh, Quill…”“Typical. And I was feeling so chipper.”“If you go through,” I said, “then—”“Yes.”I swallowed. I didn’t know what to do. “Listen,” I said, “maybe you’d better stayhere.”He did look at me, then. “What, on my own? See you all go through without me?Leave me standing here like a pillock in the dark? I don’t think so.”“But—”“Especially in these stupid feathers.”“Yes, but Quill, on the other side—”“I know,” he said. “I know. It’s got to be done right, in the proper place.”“Oh, maybe it’ll be okay,” I said desperately. “I mean, I’m only going on what theskull said, and we know what he’ s like. Talks rubbish about everything.”Kipps’s mouth pursed. He pulled his hood back, and ruffled his short red hair. Thenhe took his goggles off and, casting them aside, looked at me in that sceptical,disapproving way he had. Only this time it wasn’t me that disappointed him, buteverything that had led to this, that had brought him to be here, dressed like a bird ofparadise, in a hellish, freezing underground world, with

like a bird ofparadise, in a hellish, freezing underground world, with his life almost drained away andgone. He shook his head. “No, as soon as you said it, I sort of realised that I knewalready.” He patted the side of his cape with a pale, thin, bloodless hand. “It’s a messdown there. It’s only going one way.”“I’m so sorry, Quill.”“You need to go through, Lucy.”“Quill, you were brilliant just now.”“I know.”“Without you—”He grinned at me. “Yeah. You and Tony and the others would have never made it,

would you? Glad I made a contribution.”“Oh, God,” I said.“It’s all right. You need to go through. Can I come with you? I don’t want to goalone.” He was busy taking the cloak off as he spoke, wrestling with the awkward claspat the neck, ignoring the ice that instantly began forming on his skin. He shrugged thefeathery mass off his shoulders and offered it to me. “You want this?” he said.I shook my head. “I’m not coming back here.”“I am.”We left the cloak lying and walked together across the iron bridge. The ghosts didtheir usual. We ignored them. Halfway across I held Kipps’s hand. We passed through thepsychic vortex, the breach between worlds. Bright neon light shone ahead of us, and Icould feel life pouring back into my body. I think Quill felt it too; his grip tightened onmine, flared suddenly warm and strong. It didn’t last. We crossed the iron wall and leftthe Gate, back into our world. We were in the proper place. Before we had left thewalkway he was already falling.      V. Fittes House​23. Don’t ask me for a careful, reasoned account of what happened after that. I can’t give youone. My excuse is that when you step out through a Gate (and I’ve done this since, andknow it to be so), you’re always sick, confused and ill. You don’t see straight; everysense is shrieking with the sudden onslaught of light and sound, with the feel of warm airon your skin and in your lungs; your body goes into a kind of temporary shutdown andmuscular collapse. This is particularly marked when you’ve been over for a long time, aswe had, and it’s not a condition that makes it easy to follow what’s going on.​Grief’s similar. Sudden, unexpected grief all the more so. So don’t ask me to piecetogether the fragments I’ve retained: Lockwood dragging Kipps and me bodily clear ofthe circle; Lockwood bent over Kipps; Holly holding his hand; everyone bent over him,talking, talking to him (even I did, although what the point of that was, I don’t know,because I knew he’d gone, and I’d already said everything that was to be said on theOther Side). Holly speaking to me, holding my face in her hands; me answering, staringright through her. Lockwood, covering Kipps with our discarded cloaks (we’d torn themoff, I guess; at least, we were no longer wearing them). George just sitting there, his facestricken, the melting ice dripping from his spectacles like tears.​And Lockwood, who was the first of us to rise to his feet. Lockwood, pulling hisrapier from his belt and tapping it gently on the floor so that the last of the frost fell fromit and the blade shone bright and new. Lockwood, putting his sword back in its place,then standing silent, patient, hand on hilt, waiting for us to recover.It took a while. What a mess we were, all feathers and fur and snot and melted ice,our faces blue, our eyes puffed and red. What a pointed contrast with the orderly room inwhich we found ourselves. Okay, sure, it had a massive ghostly maelstrom at its heart,but all that whirring chaos was nicely contained within the iron circle. Once across thebridge, as we were now, you found a brightly lit and white-washed room with all thesterile neatness of an operations room in a hospital. Racks of goggles and silver suitshung along the walls, each one carefully named and numbered; there were wheeledplastic bins with a few discarded suits; a pair of stilts, leaning casually in a corner like the

severed legs of an idling drunkard; even a few safety notices by the doors.​You could tell they took a pride in keeping things just so. One side arch led onto atiled washroom, where open shower cubicles showed where the workers scrubbed upafter a hard shift beyond the Gate. Another led to an equipment room, packed out withranks of shining weapons used on the Other Side. But it was a third arch I was interestedin: the biggest of all and the twin of the one we’d entered by. This room beyond seemedfilled with cylinders; in the distance, you could see the stairs and several sets of shiningelevators. I knew one other thing that would be in that room, too.​I got slowly to my feet. I left the others and went to get the ghost-jar.​It was sitting precisely where I’d expected; on a laboratory table, in the equivalentposition to where the youth stood on the Other Side. The room, of course, had the samedimensions as the cavern where I’d seen him, but instead of ice and rubble, I had to pickmy way round well-scrubbed lab tables, technicians’ chairs, centrifuges, scales, humminggenerators and any amount of sinister experimental equipment I can’t put a name to.Many of the cylinders were connected by pipes to sealed chambers, where drifts of brightand shining substance floated drearily. The place had a chemical smell. Rows of neonceiling lights lit everything and made my eyes hurt. Actually, everything was hurting meright then, and my body was not the half of it.​The ghost-jar throbbed with a truculent green light, as if in deliberate attempt to defythe pristine whiteness all around. Inside the glass, I caught the face doing somethingimprobable with its tongue and nostrils. When it saw me shambling over, it flinched andraised its eyebrows in simulated horror. I caught a flash of the youth for a second in theexpression, then the plasm subsided back into its normal grotesque default position.​“You look dreadful,” it said. “Like something the cat brought in. Brrr… Now I’m theone getting spooked by you.”​I leaned against the table. “You were right about Kipps,” I said. “He’s gone.”The face in the jar nodded. “Yeah. I know. I saw him pass through here just a minuteago.”“You saw him?” I stared round the laboratory, at the humming generators, theglistening cylinders, the antiseptic walls. It was a room that had no shadows, and noprospect of one. There was nowhere that a ghost might hide.“Oh, he’ s not here now,” the face said. “I saw him on the Other Side. He passedthrough, as I say; pegged it up those icy stairs and gone. He wasn’t hanging around; hehad somewhere that he needed to be. No dawdling near a dirty old Source for him.” For amoment the ichor in the jar drew back and I saw the skull grinning at me. “He looked allright, you know,” the ghost added. “You needn’t worry.”I said nothing.“Personally I think he was just glad to get shot of those stupid feathers before he died.Can you imagine having to wear them for all eternity?” The plasm fizzed back into thesemblance of a face. “Anyway, moving on… what super adventures are we having next?”I made no attempt to answer, but picked up the jar. It was all I could do to carry it. Mystrength had not yet come back, and my legs felt wobbly as I walked. But before I couldreturn to the room with the Gate, Lockwood and the others came through the arch to joinme.No, not all the others, of course. Just Holly and George.We’d all looked

the others, of course. Just Holly and George.We’d all looked better. Our clothes had an oddly faded quality, like the cover of abook that’s been kept too long in the sun. Our limbs dragged. We felt ill-fitting in ourskins.  Lockwood’s dark eyes fixed on me. They said a lot, and my eyes answered them. Allthat was actually spoken, though, was crisp and business-like. “If you’re ready, Lucy,” hesaid, “it’s time to go upstairs.”I rested the jar on a table. “I’m ready.”“Good. You and I are taking the silver lift. We’re going to see Marissa. Holly andGeorge, you’ll take the stairs, or one of the bronze lifts, to the ground floor, where—”“Wait,” Holly said. “No. That’s not right. You can’t do this without us. You’ll needus, and besides, I want to see Marissa myself.” Her hand tightened on her sword hilt.“Seconded.” George adjusted his glasses on his swollen nose. One of the lenses wascracked; the other had fallen away. “We all owe her.”

“Very true,” Lockwood said, “but you two are taking a bronze lift, even so.”“Why?” Holly said. “Why should we?”​“Because I ask you to.”Neither Holly nor George answered, but their Lockwood & Co. discipline kicked in.After a long pause, both gave little nods.  ​“Right,” Lockwood said, “now listen to me. I gave him therun-down of what we’d discovered, and what we thought might happen. I also told himwe might end up here, and what we’d try to do. Of course, I thought that we’d get here ina matter of hours, not a full day later, and that might have skewed things for us. Butmaybe it’s worked to our advantage. Heaven knows what Barnes has been up to in themeantime, but he’ll have surely discovered what happened at Portland Row. Maybe he’llhave even seen our Gate. The question now is whether he can help us in any way. I thinkhe can. DEPRAC’s compromised, for sure, but it’s not all Fittes’s people by any means.”​“When we saw Marissa on the staircase,” Holly said, “she mentioned troubleoutside.”​“Yes, she did. Maybe that’s Barnes. Maybe it isn’t. But I want you two to get outsideand make contact with him. If it’s humanly possible, get him down here. Take some ofthis equipment with you as evidence. Cylinders, cloaks, whatever you can.”“We might stop off in that weapons store,” George said darkly. “Get a bit of insurancefor the road.”Lockwood’s smile was wolf-like. “I think that’s a very good idea. Oh, and keep youreye open for Flo.”​“Why?” George asked. “What will Flo be doing? She’s not hanging round too, isshe?”​“Maybe. I asked her for help as well.”There was a silence.“What about Quill?” Holly asked suddenly. “It seems wrong that… that no one’sstaying with him.”“No one needs to stay with him,” I said. “He’s gone. The skull saw him go.” I lookedoff across the lab. I knew they’d be watching me, hoping for more, but I couldn’t meettheir gaze. “He said he looked all right,” I added. That was all the reassurance I couldoffer them. There was nothing else to say. The door to the silver lift was identical to the one in the Hall of Heroes, four floors aboveus. It was inscribed with the Fittes emblem: a noble unicorn, rampant, holding a lantern inits hoof. The metal had been polished until it shone. There was a tortoiseshell button onthe wall, and a floor dial overhead, showing numbers from -4 to 7. Right now the arrowpointed to 7, the penthouse floor. That was where we were going. Lockwood pressed thebutton; from somewhere came a faint, smooth hum, as distant mechanisms eased intoaction. We waited, gazing at the door. From behind us came Holly and George’s softvoices as they rifled the weapons in the armoury.​The arrow flicked anti-clockwise back across the dial; the whirring sound grewlouder. Presently there was a melodic ting, the humming stopped; the door slid open. Itwas a dark interior of gold filigree and inlaid tortoiseshell, with mirrored panels on thesides.Lockwood and I stepped in and turned to face the front. I adjusted the ghost-jar underone

and I stepped in and turned to face the front. I adjusted the ghost-jar underone arm, and pressed the button for the seventh floor.​The door closed; almost imperceptibly, the lift began rising.“Going up,” the skull said. “Next floor: cutlery, condiments and underpants.”We stood staring at the door. There was a mirror there too. Thanks to that and the softwarm light on the ceiling, we had a lovely, lingering view of just how weak and ill welooked. Our faces were puffy and sallow. Lockwood’s hair was sticking out at impossibleangles; mine sagged over my eyes. Our clothes (the bits that remained) were blackened,faded, torn and dirty.  It was a beautiful lift, plush and evidently very old; a private lift for an exclusive

passenger. The air was heavy with a strong perfume, which I recognised very well.“Yes, she’ s been here just now,” the skull remarked. “You can feel her scent. I call it‘Flowers and Death’. A classic combination.” It hummed a jaunty tune to itself, rollingits eyes extravagantly as it watched the arrow flicking slowly across the dial.We reached Level O – the ground floor – and continued smoothly on.Lockwood pulled back the side of his tattered jacket and inspected the contents of hisbelt. I checked my sword; the Velcro clasp had deteriorated on the Other Side, but Ithought it would just hold. The hammer was still there, and a couple of packets of ironfilings. I had no flares.“So then,” the skull said, as we passed the second floor, “just fill us in, while we’vegot a moment. What’ s the plan when we meet Big M?”Neither of us answered. We watched the dial.“Here’ s my theory,” the skull said. “Lucy keeps her chatting; while the old girl’ sdistracted, Lockwood shimmies over and stabs her with a letter-opener off her desk.Sneaky, but effective. Or why don’t you grab a leg each and toss her off the balcony, soshe falls seven storeys into the mud-banks of the Thames? Splat!” It waited. “Toocomplicated for you? Okay, my last offer. You both strip naked, daub charcoal on yourcheeks – and I’m not specifying which ones – and rush out of the lift, whooping andshrieking, before hacking her to pieces with your swords. Yeah – on reflection, I thinkthat’ s the strategy for you.”We watched the dial. The arrow pointed to the fourth floor.The face looked from Lockwood to me and back again. “You have got a plan, Isuppose?”​The fifth… the sixth… You could hear the mechanism slowing.​I swallowed. Lockwood took a deep, slow breath.​Ting! The bell rang cheerfully to tell us we were there. The lift stopped with scarcelythe slightest judder.Neither of us turned our heads, but our eyes met in the mirror. We drew our swords.​The door eased open. It would have suited the moment if we’d at once had a clear view up some kind of sinisterthrone room with a red carpet in the middle, and bowing flunkies and ranks of gibberingghosts watching on either side. In actuality all we got was a small vestibule, or waitingroom, with a couple of chairs in it, and some nondescript modern art on the wall. To ourright, however, were two double doors. Lockwood pushed one open. A bright andcheerful light issued from inside, along with the sound of classical music playing. Therewas the heady scent of flowers. Lockwood and I tightened our grips on our rapiers andslipped inside.​And then? No thrones. No flunkies. In fact the room beyond wasn’t sinister at all,though it was imposing in a senior management sort of way, being the kind of place thatchief executives entertained clients before signing important deals. It was a broad,rectangular space, with a deep white carpet, and low-backed sofas ranged against thewalls. They looked angular, modish and uncomfortably fashionable. Each had glasscoffee tables beside them, scattered with books and magazines.At the far end of the room was a desk, and a wide, deep window that looked out overthe Thames and London. It was night, as the skull had told us, and the river was a deepblack band running between the brightly jewelled banks. How beautiful it looked from sohigh up, this precious, beleaguered city, stretched out dark and glittering with all itsimperfections smoothed away. The

stretched out dark and glittering with all itsimperfections smoothed away. The ghost-lamps were just pretty lights, twinkling likestars. You couldn’t see the people in it, either the living or the dead.The only curious thing about the room – and I scarcely noticed it at first, beingpreoccupied with the woman who waited for us, smiling, at the desk – was the profusionof mirrors on the walls. There were a lot of them: big ones, small ones, mirrors in plainwood, mirrors in ornate gilt frames. Indeed, apart from the window, some bookshelves,and a single white door on the left-hand side, the walls were mostly covered with them.There were even a couple of large free-standing floor-mirrors here and there, sopositioned that they multiplied the reflections from the wall and a person might see

themselves reflected from several different angles.The Orpheus Society had had a thing with clocks. Mirrors were what counted here.  Aside from all that glass, the main item of furniture was the great oak desk sat in frontof the window, piled high with books and papers, and with two jars of white lilies ateither end. It looked expensive and contemporary, the perfect place for a busy chiefexecutive to work. And in front of it, with her chair swivelled half towards us and onewhite elbow leaning casually on the desktop behind, was that chief executive herself.Ms Fittes seemed no more put out at our sudden appearance in her private chambersthan if we were old friends she’d bumped into in the street. Without the hooded silvercape and boots, she was suddenly back in slick and elegant businessperson mode, with abottle-green knee-length dress and high-heeled shoes. Her long dark hair was doing thatflowing, full-bodied thing, all lush and loose and impeccably aligned – the sort of effectyou get (I’m told) if you devote untold hours to grooming, instead of simply eating,sleeping and keeping yourself alive, which is how it works for me. I had a sudden clearperception of how important her beauty was for her, how tightly its maintenance kept herconstrained. The mirrors told their story. The windows opened out on London, but thewhole apartment reflected in on her.She sat at ease in her fashionable chair of leather and chrome, with one arm bentbehind her and the other draped casually across her lap. Her pale hand hung relaxed; abracelet of green stones dangled on her wrist. There were no weapons nearby and no oneelse in the room. She smiled at us and bid us enter.“Anthony and Lucy,” she said. “How pleasant it is to see you both. Come on over.You’re too far away for me to see you, skulking at the door.”So deep and melodious was her voice, so calm was she in her smart, sophisticatedroom, that even then we hesitated, acutely conscious of our ruined clothes, our grimy,bloodied faces. I looked down at the pristine carpet, my blackened boots planted on them.On either side the mirrors coolly reflected our ragged forms, our drawn swords, our feral,vagrant air.“Come over,” Ms Fittes said again. “There are seats for visitors.” With a flick of thefingertips she indicated two canvas armchairs near the desk. “Please don’t be shy to usethem. I can always have them cleaned.”With that remark, our hesitation melted clean away. My teeth clamped tight together. Isqueezed my rage tight in a vice; cold and bitter fury trickled downwards through me,dripping across my heart. This would be for Kipps, this would be for George; this wouldbe for the city ranged behind the calm, complacent woman at the desk. The sensation wasnot dissimilar from that which had possessed me at the Orpheus Society. I almost lostcontrol. Shaking, I raised my sword and walked across the carpet towards her, Lockwoodat my side.“Careful,” the skull said in my ear. “You must feel it.”Yes. I did. Somewhere close, another presence. But at this time it kept itself cloakedand silent. It was shadowed from the probing of my mind.“She’s not alone, Lockwood,” I murmured.“I know.”The weariness he’d shown below had fallen from him; the old light shone in hisravaged face.We didn’t take the chairs, but came to a halt a few feet away from the woman. Shehadn’t moved, but just watched us with her big, black eyes.“Swords, Anthony?” Ms Fittes said. “I’m surprised at you.” Her eye lit on the

“I’m surprised at you.” Her eye lit on the jarunder my arm. “And, Lucy – what’s this bottled abomination? Some pet Lurker? How long had she willinglylain to sleep in the next room, with it close enough to touch? There was no silver-glasscase, no iron, no lavender here – nothing to hem it in. This was its room, as much asMarissa’s – perhaps more so. They stood the two of them, gazing at us. It was the end.“I thought so, Anthony,” Marissa said again, very slowly and distinctly. She glancedat her companion. “Which is why we’re going to kill you now.”  ​25. And Lockwood moved. He had been readying himself for it ever since I’d returned to theroom. He’d known it would come to this. At some point during the conversation, he haddecided on his course of action; now, almost before Marissa had finished speaking, heacted. No hesitation, no delay: the leap was faster than thought. Marissa and the spiritwere taken entirely unawares. Perhaps even now they underestimated him, taken in byoutward appearances – by his wounds and ragged clothes. Perhaps the spirit was also distracted – ithad been growing increasingly enraged by the rude faces the skull was making at it frombehind its glass. Or perhaps Lockwood, as so often, was simply quicker than everyonearound him. That’s what I like to believe. He remained one step ahead of everybody, rightto the last.​It also helped that he did the opposite of what our enemies expected. He didn’t run.He didn’t try a long-distance assault with canister or flare. Instead he jumped directly atMarissa and the spirit. reforming, the plasm flowing together, gushing upwards and downwards like awaterfall seen reflected in a lake. That was the trouble with powerful spirits. We’d known something was up on the ground floor of Fittes House, but until thatmoment neither Lockwood nor I had had the leisure to guess precisely what. We knew itwas big. We knew Marissa wasn’t happy about it. We could guess that our friends werethoroughly involved. Behind it all, a loud psychicconcussion beat at our heads; I heard ghosts’ voices howling.​We stepped out of the lift, swords in hand, then jerked aside as a man in a Fittesuniform erupted from the smoke and ran past us, screaming.
