Thebodies of several men and women lay scattered about, DEPRAC officers and members ofthe Fittes militia. Some lay in pools of blood; others, the victims of ghost-touch, werealready swollen and blue. But there was movement in the shadows and, I thought, thesound of rapiers. And since Barnes and his men were behind us, that only meant onething.We began to run – Lockwood swiftly, me hobbling along. In my haste and discomfortI cut too close to one of the pillars; on its far side a faint green Spectre, with the form of awild-eyed man in chains, ducked into the floor like he was swimming in it, and bobbedup beside me, clawing with his hand. I leaped away, slashed with the sword, ran on. And

ahead of us, I saw Holly fighting with Sir Rupert, and, behind her, George lying on theground.  ​“Skull,” I said, as I went – the grey youth was flowing at my side – “now’s finallyyour chance for a spot of ghost-touch. Do what you like. You have my blessing.”​“Oh, nice one. Cheers. Does it matter which I kill? Sir Rupert, Munro, Cubbins?”“Sir Rupert, preferably.”​“Okay… I think I can remember that.” The grey youth swept forwards, arms gleefullyoutstretched.“No!” Lockwood looked back at me; he waved an angry hand. “Not ghost-touch!Leave him to me!”​The grey youth halted, rolled his eyes. “Give me a break. Can’t you slap him, Lucy?”​“Lockwood,” I shouted, “remember Kipps!”​“This is for Kipps,” he said.The sound of our voices had carried; Sir Rupert Gale turned slowly round. Behindhim, Holly subsided, her rapier held limply between her fingers. She looked exhausted;she sank to her knees.It had to be said that Sir Rupert didn’t look on top form either. His clothes were asdapper as ever: a grey-green jacket with black lapels, dark trousers, a vibrant yellow tie.But there was blood on his neck and knees. His eyes glittered in grey sockets; veins stoodout on his cheeks. When he spread his arms in welcome, an old strapping at his wristshowed the place where I’d struck him in the bedroom more than twenty four hoursearlier. He smiled broadly at us, even so.“Ah, I’m so pleased,” he said. “You did make it, then.”Lockwood came to a halt, held his rapier at his side. He gestured around at thescreaming ghosts; by their eerie lights you could see the ruined pillars, the stuccoedceiling, the panels with their painted depictions of great events in the history of psychicaldetection. “Yes, I made it. Well, what do you think? This a glamorous enough spot foryou?”​Sir Rupert grinned. “I’ve no complaints this time.”“That’s fine, then.”They raised their swords, touched them together. Lockwood brushed his hair out ofhis eyes. Then Sir Rupert sprang towards him.Three clashes, two feints, a side-step and a roll – already they were away across thehall, moving between the drifting tendrils of the Dark Spectre and the shuffling cadaverof poor Godel, weeping piteously for its missing arm. I forced myself to look away. Itwould be okay. I trusted him. I knew Lockwood and it would be fine. I knelt beside Hollyand George.Holly could barely raise her head to smile at me. George’s face was blackened withsmoke, but I couldn’t see any obvious injuries. His sword lay at his feet. Moving stiffly,he propped himself up on his elbows.“Looks like you two have been busy,” I said.  “Holly’s been amazing,” George said in a faint voice. “Kept three of them at bay,single-handed. Drove off Sir Rupert… Gave me the opportunity to do the damage here.”“We had to do it,” Holly said. “Gale had too many men; they were tearing Barnes’steam apart…”I nodded. “You did well. You’ve given us a chance. Now you need to get out.”“Found the explosives down in that basement,” George went on. “You wouldn’tbelieve the weapons they’ve got down there… The ones I used to

the weapons they’ve got down there… The ones I used to bust the pillars weren’teven the most powerful bombs! There were some little silver jobs that— Wait, is that theSkull?”The grey youth had sidled closer so that it loomed over my prone companions. “It isindeed. Well, Cubbins, this is nice. We’ve a lot to discuss. Certain experiments youcarried out on me a while ago… I seem to recall electrodes, being heated in an oven…”George gave a croak. “Scientific research! No malice was intended!”“And there was the small matter of some shared baths…”All this time, I’d had the broken ghost-jar under one arm. I put it down, and helpedpull Holly to her feet, wincing at the pain in my side. “You can kill George later,” I said.

“For now, Skull, please escort them safely out. Reception’s just through there.”​Holly looked at me. “And Marissa?”​“Oh, we’ve maybe a couple of loose ends still to tidy up.”“Then—”“Please, Holly. Just for me.”She didn’t argue; she knew that they were spent. I left them hobbling together, arm inarm, following the glimmering shape of the spiky-haired youth. Left them, and turnedback to the sword fight in the hall.​They were moving back and forth between the pillars, Lockwood and Sir RupertGale, their reflections skipping across the fractured surfaces, swelling and shrinking,distorting on the jags of broken glass. Spectral shapes threw themselves towards them,mouthing shrieks and curses. Sometimes the whirling iron deterred the ghosts; othertimes the combatants simply swerved away. They made no sound but the scuff andsqueak and shuffle of their boots on the shining marble floor. In and out, foot to foot,twisting and spinning in a single synchronised flow. It was a ballet as much as a fight,with beauty as well as terror. It was a dance of death with two possible ends.​Within that dance, all weariness and injury had gone, all bodily weaknesses leftbehind. A while ago, Lockwood had been scarcely able to move, but you wouldn’t haveguessed that from his airy steps, they way he swung out of reach of the swiftest blows.Sir Rupert also; he’d looked half-dead when he’d turned to us. Yet now, from some deepwell of defiance and hatred, he had summoned renewed strength, and moved with themost light-footed grace. Neither of them spoke; the illusion was too fragile, theconcentration required to sustain it too great. One word, one mistake, and everythingwould fall away; the mask would slip and a life be lost.  “Ghost-touch would be so much simpler,” the Skull said. Its spirit had returned; ithovered beside me, arms folded, tapping a translucent finger on its sleeve.“I know.”“Are you sure I can’t just— Oh, too late.”I followed its gaze. Marissa Fittes was walking towards us across the hall.Her stolen body still seemed to be functioning well. Penelope’s long hair flapped inthe breeze that blew about her, her heels clicked purposefully on the marble floor. Herspirit companion was close behind, radiant and beautiful as ever, its drapes of swirlingother-light coiling round her in a loving gesture of support. Marissa was carryingsomething strapped over her shoulder: a metal cylinder of some kind. I was instantlyreminded of the weaponry the Orpheus members had used, but the woman didn’t seek touse it. She came to a halt a few metres from me and signalled to her companion.A snapped section of one of the pillars lay near them on the floor, jagged with spursof broken glass. The ghost’s arm swept round, and the pillar span with it, whipping acrossthe floor towards me. At my side the scrawny youth made a similar gesture. The pillar’smomentum slowed; it reversed its spin and shot back towards Marissa. The golden spiritmoved its arm; the pillar swung aside, rolled straight through the Gory Girl’s crawlingform, and smashed against the wall.The golden spirit frowned. A storm of air raged round me, met an answering windfrom the youth beside me and fell back.“This is fun,” the Skull said. “Been ages since I’ve had the chance to do anything likethis. But that pretty boy and I are evenly matched. It’ s all I can do to contain him. You’regoing to have to fix Marissa on your

can do to contain him. You’regoing to have to fix Marissa on your own.”I nodded. It hadn’t been easy getting to my feet with Holly and George just then. Myleft side was no longer quite doing its job – I found it painful to stand straight. I stoodcrunched to one side, breath gasping. Still, I was alive and legitimately so – unlike thewoman standing there.“That green bracelet on her wrist,” the Skull called. “Think that might be anything?”“Oh, you mean the Source? Yes… Maybe.”“And watch out for that cylinder. It’ s not a thermos flask of tea, put it that way.”The youth stepped away; he was a blur of movement, a centre of invisible lines offorce, feinting, probing, deflecting unseen attacks. The golden spirit followed him.Which just left the two of us, Marissa Fittes and me. We stood facing each other inthe midst of all that psychic chaos, in that ruined hall, at the heart of haunted London.

We smiled at each other.“How appropriate,” Marissa said, “that you should have that ragged, spotty spirit todefend you, this spectral urchin! How typical of you, Lucy! How typical of Lockwoodand Co.!”I shrugged. “He suits me,” I said. “And I don’t see your glossy Type Three makingany headway here.”I moved towards her, disregarding the pain in my side.“You’re hurt,” the woman said. She stepped slowly backwards, fingering the metalcylinder at her side. “You’re dying.”“Like you’re an expert on that.”“You’re bleeding to death.”“I don’t think so. One of my friends has done that already today. I know what it lookslike, Marissa. This is not the same.” I was coming steadily, one hand slippery on my side,the other with the sword held ready. “But even if I was, it wouldn’t stop me. I’d keepcoming after you. If I had to leave this world, I’d pursue you from the next.” I grinned ather. “You of all people know that’s possible, right?”You could see the fear rising in her, contorting her smooth and glossy features. Shelooked towards her spirit companion, but he and the skull were locked in psychic combat.She looked to Sir Rupert, but he was visibly weakening, desperately fighting offLockwood’s relentless advance. That lovely face didn’t look so good now that certaintyhad gone; somehow its perfect lines no longer aligned; the cheekbones seemed too high,the chin too protuberant. Complacency had glued the mask in position over the years;without it, there was an ugliness coming through.“Get away from me!” She picked up a piece of silver-glass, a fragment of one of thepillars. It smashed beside my feet. I didn’t pause.“Give me that bracelet, Marissa. Or find a sword and defend yourself. Whichever youwant to do.”All at once she was in full retreat, panicking now, stumbling, tripping on her fancyheels. She was edging towards the centre of the hall, where baying ghosts wheeled anddarted with expectation.​“I think they recognise you!” I said. “They know it’s you who put them here.”​She glanced aside in fear. I took my chance – leaping forward, I seized her arm and,with the tip of the rapier, slashed the jade bracelet from her wrist, severing its soft goldband. A violent psychic charge ran through me; I almost dropped the sword. Away acrossthe hall, her spirit companion gave a plangent cry. It turned from its confrontation withthe skull, and with glowing eyes rushed across towards me, robes flapping, mouthhideously agape. I scrabbled at my belt, pulled a silver-net from its pouch and wrapped itround the broken bracelet. The ghost seemed to disintegrate as it came, pieces fallingfrom it like molten wax, flesh peeling to bone, bone stripping away, until it was just theeyes that kept on rushing, and even these grew pale and faded to twists of smoke thatwere lost in the darkness of the hall.​A moment later the skull’s spirit appeared at my side, spiky haired, hands casuallystuffed in pockets. “Hey, stole my thunder there,” it said. “He was on the ropes. Anotherfew seconds, and I’d have had him. Was it the bracelet?”​“It was the bracelet.”“Yay. And in more good news,” the grey youth said, “Lockwood’ s just won.”I looked across. Not far away, in the

s just won.”I looked across. Not far away, in the centre of the room, Sir Rupert Gale lay spread-eagled on his back. His rapier lay beside him. His arms were bent in a strange, unnaturalway. Lockwood stood over him, chest heaving with exertion, his sword hanging looselyin his hand. There was no triumph in his posture, only exhaustion; exhaustion and a kindof regret. No matter what we’d suffered, no matter what had happened to Kipps, toGeorge, to our beautiful Portland Row, another man’s shade had gone moaning into thedark, and it was no cause for celebration.“Two down,” I said. “And now,” turning to Marissa, “there’s only one to go.”The woman stood at bay, cowering yet defiant. Technically speaking, of course, weonly saw Penelope, but there was something in the twisted contours of the body, in theway it hunched before us, in the snarling lines of the face and blazing eyes, that made itseem as if the old woman’s shrivelled spirit had exposed itself again.

“Keep back,” she said. “I’m warning you.”Lockwood walked slowly over. The skull’s spirit and I closed in on her from the otherside.“Keep away!” Marissa said again. She pulled the cylinder round so that it dangledfrom her neck. She scrabbled at it, held it in both hands. “Don’t touch me!”“You have to come with us now,” Lockwood said. “It’s over.”“I’m not coming with you. I’m not giving up to a pair of stupid children. This is myhouse. I built it. It’s mine.”“Not any more, it isn’t,” I said. “Put that thing down.”The woman clutched the cylinder tighter against her chest. “Know what this is?” shesaid. “Sometimes, on the Other Side, we have to clear wide spaces, make it safe for ourteams to get across the city. We use explosive charges like this. Then can level a wholeblock.” She gave us a lipless grin. “I’ve never tried, but I’m sure it’ll work just as wellover here. I just flick this little lever – ten seconds later, the whole thing blows. Come anycloser, I’ll do it.” She stepped slowly backwards, away from us. “Try to stop me, I’ll killus all.”“Do I count?” the Skull’s spirit said. “Strictly speaking, I’m dead already.”“Stay right there! None of you come after me.” Shadows swathed her; her eyesglinted at us. “And be sure I’ll make you regret the damage that you’ve done to metoday…”“Yeah, Marissa,” I said, “you might want to watch where you’re going.”It was too late. A faint blue glow of other-light expanded behind her; a smooth, roundface materialised at her back. The Clapham Butcher Boy was one of the slower andquieter of the nine released spirits; he had made no noise in his approach, and he made nonoise now as his great pale arms stole round Marissa and drew her to him. His slackmouth opened in welcome; his sightless eyes stared out at nothing. He was like a deep-sea fish swallowing its prey. He hugged her close, so that blue veins of ice ran swiftly upand down her skin. Her limbs jerked and thrashed; she made a gargling sound. Her handsclenched and spasmed, as she was drawn back into the dark. At her chest a little red lightshowed suddenly. There was a faintest whirring; a smell of oil and burning.I looked at Lockwood. “Wait. Did she—?”His eyes were wide. “Yes.”The Skull’s spirit stepped between us, that thin, ill-favoured youth, with his sidelongeyes and scratty hair. “She did, and there’ s no point you running. You’ll never get out intime. Better brace yourselves. Two seconds.”“She said we had ten…”He grinned at me. “I’m not talking about that.”The youth lifted his arms. The spirit-wind that struck us forced all the air from mylungs. It sent us off our feet and straight out backwards across the hall.As we flew back I saw the explosion deeper in the hall, saw a boiling plume of blackand red expand outwards at blinding speed. It cut right through the broken pillars and theghosts. It cut through the figure of the youth as he watched us go. It accelerated after us,and the windows of the Hall of Pillars burst with the oncoming heat. But we were stillahead of it, Lockwood and I. We were going too fast. It could not catch us. We went rightout through

and I. We were going too fast. It could not catch us. We went rightout through the windows with the fireball licking at our feet. We shot out over brick andconcrete and landed in the flower-beds by the road.I lay there, with Lockwood alongside, our twin furrows slicing right through theunicorn design. I saw the plume of fire erupting over our heads against a tapestry of stars.I saw black smoke swell out around us, and then I didn’t see anything for a while. My lastthought was that I’d left the ghost-jar in the hall.

VI. The Beginning​27. It was fortunate that the original builders of Fittes House had not taken any shortcuts withits construction, because – despite Marissa’s dire predictions – the explosion in the Hallof Pillars didn’t make the whole thing fall down. Most of the destruction wasconcentrated in the ground floor area, with the main force of the blast being directedstreetwards through reception, blowing out part of the front wall, and sending glass andrubble spilling across the Strand. The famous glass doors, with their inscribed unicornmotifs, were utterly obliterated. One or two walls collapsed internally, as did part of theceiling above the Hall. All traces of the silver-glass pillars and the relics they containedwere at once wiped out.​More importantly, the explosion itself claimed few extra casualties. Since it happenedat five in the morning, the surrounding streets had been mostly deserted, and the pitchedbattle that had been going on inside the building for the previous few hours had led to theevacuation of ordinary Fittes staff. The remaining DEPRAC forces, under command ofMontagu Barnes, had also got clear by way of an underground tunnel leading to theThames. As dawn broke, such survivors gathered in the Strand. Smoke hung thickly overcentral London, and a large number of onlookers began to congregate in TrafalgarSquare.Inspector Barnes, whose raincoat had sustained significant damage in the battle, castthe tattered remnants aside and commandeered a leather biker’s jacket from a bystanderin the street. For the next few hours he seemed to be everywhere, summoning ambulancesand medic-vans, regrouping his DEPRAC team, and rousing the dozens of wanderingFittes agents, who were mostly in a state of shock, to assist with crowd control. He alsorequisitioned two cafés across the street to provide a constant stream of hot food anddrinks to all.The smoke cleared; the heat in the building died down. Search and rescue teams wentin. Almost at once, they discovered a number of white-coated scientists, wide-eyed andtremulous, who had appeared from the basement levels. They were at once handed intoDEPRAC custody. Two of Sir Rupert Gale’s men, one suffering from ghost-touch, werealso located alive; they were taken off to hospital under armed guard.​By mid-morning, DEPRAC crews had cordoned off the end of the Strand, and thesituation was under full control. A census of survivors was taken, and a tentative list ofthe dead or missing formed. Bodies began to be brought out of Fittes House. Mostly thesewere ones that had been some way from the centre of the explosion. Those of Sir RupertGale and Penelope Fittes were not found. At some point during all this activity the surviving members of Lockwood & Co. went tosit at a window table in the Silver Unicorn café, directly opposite the disaster zone. Theemergency services had already taken us under their wing; our cuts had been cleaned,dressed and bandaged, and pep-shots of insulin given to us to counteract our closeexposure to ectoplasm. For each of us, a hospital visit had been offered and declined. Ihad been forced to protest particularly strongly to avoid this fate: the stab wound in myside was the most serious of our varied injuries, and an overnight stay was recommended.But I would not leave the others. In the end I was patched up, drugged and given atemporary discharge, with instructions to report to a doctor the next day. Then the medicsturfed me out. So I sat in the café with the rest of them.​There isn’t any point in describing in detail how we looked. We were just as bad asbefore, only now with added plasters and minor burns. The soles of Lockwood’s shoes

had partially melted. Even the frames of George’s glasses had gone now. He was stillwrapped in one of the silver thermal blankets we’d been given by the emergency crews; itlooked uncomfortably like a certain silver cape he’d worn recently, but none of us felt theneed to mention it. We nursed our cups of tea, our toast, whatever the harried caféproprietors had been able to get for us, for the place was packed. We stared out at theStrand.​“I don’t like to say it,” a voice said behind us, “but you lot really need to spruceyourselves up a bit.”​Flo Bones had materialised by our table. She looked precisely the same as she alwaysdid, down to the familiar stains on her puffer jacket and her mud-encrusted boots. Herstraw hat was perched on her head at a jaunty angle, and she was spooning something hotand flavoursome from a polystyrene dish into her mouth.“Look at the state of you all!” she said, shaking her head. “It’ll get soon as I won’tlike to be seen in your company. Some of us have standards, you know.”“Hello, Flo,” Lockwood said. “You look in excellent shape. I’m glad.”“Yeah, I’m just dandy. Just enjoying a bit of pie and mash here too.”George gave a start. “Pie and mash? Where’d you get that from?”“Next door. You’re in the wrong café. They do jellied eels there, and all.”George groaned into his mug of tea. “The best they can do here is fish-pastesandwiches. And it’s too late to switch. All my muscles have seized up.”Lockwood half rose from his chair and gave Flo a fleeting hug. “You were amazinglast night,” he said. “Barnes has told me everything you did. How many of Sir Rupert’sthugs did you account for again?”​Flo’s blue eyes stared off across the Strand. “I’m not sure I can remember.” She madea scraping noise with her spoon. “You did well and all, Locky. Didn’t think you’d makeit.”​“We didn’t,” Lockwood said. “Not all of us.”​“No. Well.” Flo glanced over at the café door, where Inspector Barnes was loudlygiving orders to an officer behind him. “Looks like it’s maybe time to go. DEPRACofficers and me don’t normally see eye to eye. Even when we’ve been squeezing up asewer tunnel together.”​“A sewer? Barnes told us it was a sluice gate…”​But Flo had already faded back into the café crowd.​With gruff apologies, Inspector Barnes pushed his way past the tea queues to ourtable. He had one arm in a sling, protruding from beneath his leather jacket.Lockwood pulled himself higher in the chair, squared his shoulders and put on a fairattempt at his most gleaming smile. “Nice jacket, Mr Barnes,” he said. “It suits you.”The Inspector regarded himself. “You know, I think it does. I might well keep it. So,you’re all fed and watered then, I see. Anything else you need?”“A plate of pie and mash would go down a treat,” George said. “If you’re offering.”“I’m not. And they’re all out of that next door. One of my men just asked. What Ireally came to tell you is that we’re scaling down the search on the ground floor. It’s amess, particularly in that

scaling down the search on the ground floor. It’s amess, particularly in that hall. Everything there’s been destroyed.”  “Everything?” I asked.Barnes shrugged. “Most everything. The good news is those ruddy Sources in thatroom will all have been blown to powder. Anyway, there’s nothing more we can do nowwithout heavy equipment.”“Have you tried the basement yet?” Holly asked. “There’s plenty for you to see downthere. Particularly on the deepest level. That’s where we got the explosives. And… andmost importantly—”“Most importantly,” Lockwood said, “Quill Kipps is there. We need him brought up,please.”Barnes nodded pouchily. “I understand. As to the rest, I’ll deal with it in good time. Ican do it in conjunction with my interrogation of those white-coats we found skulkingdown below.”“Most of the Fittes crowd will have had nothing to do with it,” Lockwood said. “It’s

just a very small group of them – an inner core – who worked on the secret project. Butthe same isn’t true of the members of the Orpheus Society, and they’re powerful people.What are you going to do about them?”“I don’t know yet!” The inspector glared at us. “I don’t know! There are big decisionsto be made, and much to be done.” He sighed and rubbed his eyes.“There’s one more thing you might want to prioritise, Mr Barnes,” I said. “You’ll findit behind some curtains in a bedroom on the top floor. Marissa’s body.”The Inspector winced. “Not so loud, please, Ms Carlyle! We don’t want everyoneoverhearing this.” He looked anxiously across at the café crowd.“Even so,” I said, “you’ll want to dispose of… the object pretty quickly. Might Isuggest it’s taken to the mausoleum up the road? That’s where she ought to be, after all.”“There’s someone there who’ll be very pleased to see her,” Holly said. She took afastidious sip of tea.Barnes straightened; he had noticed one of his men signalling at the door. “We’ll seewhat we can do. Well, I’ll leave you for the present. There are legions of reportersclamouring for a statement. In the meantime, rest up, don’t leave, and don’t talk toanybody here.”“At least the truth will come out now,” Lockwood said. He had been looking towardsthe square, where the anxious crowds were continuing to grow. It gave us an oddsensation to think of them. It wasn’t the first gathering we’d seen in Trafalgar Square thatday.​Barnes patted him on the shoulder. “Ah yes,” he said. “About all that. You and Iclearly need to have a little chat.”​In the event, our consultations at Scotland Yard lasted the entire afternoon. The DEPRACcars didn’t drop us back at the end of Portland Row until gone five. You could feel theonset of evening in the air, but the sky was still blue, and the rusted ghost-lamps were notyet buzzing into life. The momentous events in central London had yet to resonate here.Many of the houses had their doors and windows still open, and children were playing inthe pavements and the basement yards. The purple-blue splendour of the lavender bushespressing against the railings almost gave the street the feel of a formal garden. At gatesand porches, beneath twinkling silvery defences, neighbours discussed the events of theday. Old Arif, standing outside his General Stores, was tipping last night’s lavender ashout of his street brazier, before readying another fire. His humming, the laughter of thechildren and the voices of the adults merged and mingled on the ear.We headed slowly, painfully, up the road.The front of 35 Portland Row didn’t look too bad. Apart from the magnesium stainson the path, the brightly coloured DEPRAC tape wound messily across the gate, and theContaminated Zone warning signs plastered on the old black door you might almost havethought nothing had happened there.Lockwood pulled the tape off the gate, crumpled it into a sticky ball and cast it aside.He put his hand on the metal cross-piece, but didn’t push it open.We stood outside in the street looking up at the house.There wasn’t much obvious external damage. Only one of the windows was broken.But we could see the remains of our boards over the inside of the basement windows, andthe ones upstairs looked dark and hollow. There was salt and iron crusted on the path too,presumably left by Barnes’s

salt and iron crusted on the path too,presumably left by Barnes’s team.​How many times in our careers had we stood like this outside a building renderedterrible by a haunting, where some violent incident or trauma had scarred it psychicallydown the years? How many times had we picked up our kit bags and strolledpurposefully in? We never delayed. Dawdling on the threshold wasn’t our thing.All through the aftermath in the Strand and Scotland Yard, we had maintained ourcomposure and our energies. Now, suddenly, a great weariness descended on us. Westood frozen at the threshold of our own ravaged house.It was Holly who drew herself up and pushed open the gate.“Come on,” she said briskly, “let’s get it over with.”

28. THE ULTIMATE BETRAYAL  Occult experiments in heart of LondonPenelope Fittes involvement goes back yearsInside today: M U Barnes and A J Lockwood finally speak outExtraordinary developments continued yesterday in the Fittes House Scandal, a full weekafter explosions rocked central London, killing company head Penelope Fittes and manyothers, and leading to revelations that have turned the psychical defence industry upsidedown. With Fittes House itself still under quarantine, and many employees remainingunder arrest, DEPRAC officials have been slow to provide details either of the hiddenlaboratories discovered beneath the building or of the secret raid that brought them tolight. Now, in an exclusive interview with today’ s Times of London, two heroes of theraid, Mr Montagu Barnes of DEPRAC and Mr Anthony Lockwood of the Lockwood &Co. agency, set the record straight.​“In the basement levels of Fittes House,” Mr Lockwood says, “we discoveredevidence of unnatural occult experiments using forbidden psychic relics. Stockpiles ofillegal explosives were also found, some of which were set off in the fighting that followedour arrival. Many brave DEPRAC agents lost their lives when the criminals attacked.And Lockwood & Co. is mourning the death of our most valued friend, Mr Quill Kipps.Without Quill, none of this would have been uncovered. I’d like to pay tribute to him.”​According to Mr Barnes, the scale of the occult activity was enough to threateneveryone in London, and possibly further afield. “We are investigating the nature of thesewicked experiments and will continue to do so. There’ s no question however thatPenelope Fittes was orchestrating them, and had been for many years. It’ s a grievousbetrayal of everything her grandmother stood for. Marissa Fittes will be turning in hergrave.”Several close associates of Ms Fittes, at the Sunrise Corporation and other majoragency supply companies, have also been arrested. DEPRAC emphasises, however, thatthe public need not fear a breakdown in our national paranormal defences. The Fittesand Rotwell agencies are being reconstituted as the United Agency, under the temporarycontrol of Mr Barnes. “Rest assured,” he says, “that this scandal, shocking though it is,will not deter psychical investigations agencies, big and small, from continuing to serveyou in our ongoing battle with the Problem.”Full Barnes and Lockwood Interview: see page 3-6Decline and Fall – the Story of the Fittes Dynasty: see pages 8-11Mr Quill Kipps – Memories of an Unsung Hero: see page 16 “What amazes me, Lockwood,” I said, looking at him over the top of the newspaper, “ishow much you manage to say here, and how little. You and Barnes are as bad as eachother now. I’m surprised you’re not growing a little bog-brush moustache.”​Lockwood was sitting with his elbow resting on the kitchen table, luxuriating in apatch of morning sun. He had on a new white shirt, and since it was a new whitetablecloth too, on a nice new table, on a sunny morning, the effect was almost enough tomake you shield your eyes. He smiled ruefully. “I know what you mean, Luce. Thoughmost of it’s accurate enough, in its way.”I folded the newspaper (George would want it for his files) and placed it neatly on thecounter by the sink. andcertainly nothing about the spirit gate or the Other Side. Can you get us a new jam, Hol?”​Holly had been gathering breakfast materials in one of the kitchen cupboards. Eeesh, they look healthy.

ofsunflower seeds and funny little nut things. Eeesh, they look healthy. They’re not evensalted. The kitchen had

been one of the worst affected portions of the house, with its doors and windowsshattered, most of its furniture destroyed, and bloodstains and scorch marks on thelinoleum floor. So we’d stripped the linoleum, and removed the broken cupboards. Thewindows had been replaced. A new back door, unpainted, awaited our attention. Our realpriority had been the table and its Thinking Cloth. With these in place, it was possible tofunction again. The house would be all right. Like us, it was taking time to heal.​And it was a beautiful morning to be healing in. In the garden, the tree was dark andheavy with apples. The rings of burnt grass below the steps and outside the basementdoor were almost lost in the general greenness. Soon I would pick the apples – I wouldmake time for that this year – and reseed the lawns. We would repaint the windows andrepair our basement office. We would build new straw dummies and hang them in therapier room. We would restock our shelves and walls with books and curios. Newartefacts would be found (almost all of Lockwood’s parents’ collection had beensurrendered to the Gate in Jessica’s room, and since removed by DEPRAC anddestroyed), and new furniture bought. Theskull was sitting by my plate, very charred and blackened, but otherwise grinning out atus as insolently as ever. I could see why Holly objected to its presence, but I didn’t care.​“Silent.”​“No change, then?”​No, there hadn’t been any change. The jar had been mangled and melted in the heat; the skull, however, though seared and cracked, had survived intact. I had pulled it clear, wrapped itup, and kept it with me ever since, just in case. But nothing had happened. Whenever Iput my fingers on it, I got no psychic charge. But that’s because their Sources were destroyed. Here’s his Source,” I said.“I saved it. That explosion wouldn’t destroy his spirit, would it?”​“I don’t know. Maybe.”​“It wouldn’t. I’m sure it wouldn’t.”​“Or disrupt his connection with it.”​“No. That doesn’t make sense. I guess it’s true he won’t come back in daylight. He’snot protected from the sun by the silver-glass now that he’s out of the jar. But at nighttime… that’s when he should come back.”That’s what I kept telling myself, but I didn’t actually believe my theory. It had been aweek now and he hadn’t returned.​“Could be he’s just… gone, Luce,” Holly said. “You freed him from the jar. Hehelped us in return. Maybe that’s encouraged him to do what he should have done acentury ago – which is move on.”She was probably right. We ate our breakfast. After a while Lockwood said, “Okay,there’s one bit of important business to attend to this morning. Yesterday Barnes gave methose official DEPRAC papers, which we all need to sign. You know, they’re the oneswhere we promise not to make public statements about what we saw at Fittes House,about the Other Side – all the secret stuff, basically.”“I don’t like having to sign this,” I said.“I know you don’t, Luce. None of us are particularly comfortable about it. But don’tforget that Barnes has his side of the deal to follow too, as a quid pro quo. The Gate atFittes House is not being destroyed. DEPRAC is undertaking to try to fix this whole mess

and clear up whatever… obstructions have been placed on the Other Side by Marissa andher associates.”“The silver nets,” Holly said.“The nets, yes, and whatever else they’ve been doing. The trouble is we don’t yetreally understand how this operation worked. We don’t really know how the spirits’essence was used, or how far they went to gather it. For instance, we don’t know whetherthere are any other Gates, which seems probable, as the Problem’s spread so far acrossthe country.”“Our friends at the Orpheus Society might help,” George said, “and the scientistsfrom Fittes House, if DEPRAC gives them a bit of persuasion.”“I’m sure they will. Anyway, that’snot for us to worry about—” Lockwood broke off and looked round the table at us.“Unless…” I said.It was the old Lockwood grin, the one that spoke of boundless energy and confidence,the sense that anything could be achieved. “Unless,” he said, “we want to accept aproposal Barnes has made. Because DEPRAC needs our help with all this. AndLockwood and Co.’s uniquely valuable, because of what we’ve done already.”There was a silence.“You mean go back to the Other Side?” George said.Holly blinked. “Put on those cloaks again? Remove those nets?”“That certainly could be part of it,” Lockwood said, “but that’s not all. They’ll needhelp researching all the documents in the Orpheus and Fittes archives. They’ll need tomap Dark London, and perhaps beyond.” He’d been addressing George while saying this;now he looked at Holly. “They also need our help drawing up new agency guidelines,too, ones which better respect the rights and opinions of young agents. And Lucy—”Here his eyes met mine— “they’ll need help trying to communicate with the spirits onthe Other Side. Take it from me, Barnes knows there’s lots to do.” He sat back and smiledat us. “Anyway, there’s no urgency in making our response. He just asked us to thinkabout it, that’s all.”Which was fine. Our immediate response was to eat more breakfast.​“You know what my theory is,” George said after a while. “Dark London? That’s justan interim stage. You linger awhile, then move on. Those black gates…”“Gates? I saw them as doors,” Holly said.“Black pools,” Lockwood said. “Hanging vertically. Just feel it.”“That’s not like you.”“You’ll have to write a book about it,” Lockwood said. “If you do it quick, andpublish it when we fix the Problem, lots of people will buy it and we can make somemoney.”“Not that we’re going to be paupers, anyway,” Holly said. “Even if we don’t takeBarnes up on his offer, there are hundreds of calls waiting for us to respond to them.Some really juicy cases. waiting for us to respond to them.Some really juicy cases. With Fittes and Rotwell in such a bad light, we’re set to be themost popular agency in London if we choose. There’s a bleeding barrel, a Raw-bones on a barge…”​She went on telling me. Lockwood wrote lists on the cloth. George stole a pen anddid a dubious cartoon. I drank some tea and sat in the morning sunlight. The skull staredpeaceably out at nothing. I hadn’t lied to Holly. I was happy with my little attic bedroom. Almost alone of all therooms in the house it had been overlooked by our enemies after our flight through theGate, and was just the same as it had always been. I often went there, in the evenings ofthose numb and quiet days, to rest and think a little under the low-slung eaves.That evening was no different. The windowsill was bathed in the last warm dregs ofsunshine. You could see rings in the dust where the ghost-jar used to sit. I put theblackened skull on the sill in its traditional place and looked down into Portland Row.The sky was grey and pink, and the sun was shining on the houses on the oppositeside, making them glittery with life. White curtains shone, and the ghost wards in theirwindows sparkled. Children were playing in the street below.There was a knock at the door. I turned and answered, and Lockwood looked in. Hehad his new long coat on, as if ready to go out, and was clutching a sheaf of papers to hischest.​“Hi, Lucy. Sorry to disturb.”​“That’s fine. Come on in.”It was nice to see him. Certain

fine. Come on in.”It was nice to see him. Certain things had been said between us during the heat of thecrisis, on Primrose Hill and elsewhere. In the days since, we hadn’t mentioned themagain. This was okay by me. We were all of us exhausted, emotionally washed up. Noneof us wanted to do anything much other than eat and sleep and enjoy the simplemechanics of being alive. hacking at the broken library shelves…”​I held up my hand. “Yeah, okay. I can see what you’re holding. That wretchedDEPRAC statement. All right, I’ll sign it, but not now.
